title: Between 3 May 2019 and 1 November 2019, which of the following will happen first in relation to the Brexit process?
possible_answers: The UK will leave the EU with the November 2018 Withdrawal Agreement in place
The UK will leave the EU with a new or renegotiated version of a Withdrawal Agreement in place
The UK will leave the EU without a Withdrawal Agreement in place
The UK's Article 50 period will be extended beyond 31 October 2019
The UK will set a date for a General Election
The UK will set a date for a referendum on Brexit
correct_answer: The UK's Article 50 period will be extended beyond 31 October 2019
preds: Boris accepts EU proposal, parliament rejects BJ proposal of election date.

As others have said the EU has agreed to Extend A50 until 31st Jan 2020. Even if the paperwork has not been completed, if we assume that the English law rule applies the written document only acts as evidence that the verbal agreement was made. (I have no idea if EU law uses the same assumption.) An observation; one reason for the Brexit mess is that hardly anyone is thinking strategically, all the effort is being put into tactics. What does BJ really want? He says he wants his cake but to be able to eat it too, but what exactly does that mean? He says he wants to do wonderful trade deals with non-EU countries. That sounds fine, but what countries is he talking about? What goods and services does he think trade could be improved in? What evidence is there that these other counties want trade deals that would benefit the UK? BJ's trade advisors have said that their vision of free trade would lead to a decline of UK manufacturing and agriculture, and that the UK should be a provider of services. What services?  What jobs would the former agricultural and manufacturing works do? Unless we know what types of jobs these displaced workers will do, how can the retraining start? The whole Brexit idea seems to be based on the EU being a problem that is holding back the UK and if the EU is removed that will automatically improve the UK, and no one need spend time or effort on figuring out how. 
Its a similar to the ideas of the Neoconservatives regarding Iraq; get rid of Saddam Hussein and some how the middle east will sort itself out. No need to worry about how, it will happen by itself. It didn't. 
A good Brexit requires a well thought out deliverable destination, and then a strategy on how to get to the destination. BJ does not do plans, he does tactics and opportunities.  The opposition are no better. Corbyn's message seems to be vote for me because I am a good person and I will do good things, they must be good because I am a good person. Anything that I do that does not appear good, only appears not to be good because you are failing to see the good.

Between 3 May 2019 and 1 November 2019, which of the following will happen first in relation to the Brexit process? @Tetbury provides an excellent analysis considering factors most of us don't appreciate.

It was inevitable that this question would throw up problems to the last minute, as it has done all the way though. On Monday the PM will try and get a GE via the Fixed Term Parliament Act (which requires a 2/3 majority). Its not clear that if he wins the vote that he will legally set the date for the GE, because the FTPA allows the PM to then choose the date. I am pretty sure he would choose 12 Dec, but legally he would probably not do so until the EU had extended A50. But the PM wants to link the GE to an agreement to complete the Parliamentary progress of his WA Bill. This would need to be completed by 6th Nov. Its very unlikely that MPs will agree the timetable for the WA Bill. So this method of getting to a GE will almost certainly will not work, if it were the date would probably not be set until after A50 had been extended.  A new idea from the LibDems and SNP is to have a Short Bill, setting aside the FTP Act that would call for a GE on 9th Dec, if A50 has been extended. This would only require a simple majority of MPs and so has more chance of becoming law because the Conservatives, LibDems and SNP have the numbers. Labour might also think they also have to support it as well. The problem for this as far a the PM is concerned is that there would not be time to pass his WA B. So this has a chance of happening (30%?) but if it is conditional on the EU agreeing to Extend A50 to 31st Jan (as the LIBDems are saying it is) then logically the A50 extension would be before the GE date is set. (i can see some argument being possible, but if we follow the normal invitation, offer, accept  sequence of a contract, then the A50 extension would be before the GE date was set.) There is also a possible time problem with this plan. It requires a complete bill to pass, it would be tight to complete by 31st Oct and any extension to A50 has to happen  by then even if the bill is incomplete. If the bill is not complete before 4th Nov the GE could not take place on 9th Dec.

UK’s Johnson seeks Dec. 12 election to break Brexit impasse Lawless (2019) October 24, states that: LONDON (AP) — British Prime Minister Boris Johnson has finally abandoned his promise of an October Brexit and pinned his hopes on a December election (Para. 1). Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn said he would wait and see whether the EU agreed to delay Britain’s departure from the bloc. Johnson grudgingly asked for a three-month delay until Jan. 31 on the orders of Britain’s Parliament, which wants to avert the economic damage that could come from a no-deal exit (Para. 7). “Take no-deal off the table and we absolutely support a general election,” Corbyn said. He said that “if the EU will answer tomorrow then we’ll know tomorrow.” Smaller opposition parties said they wanted an election but were wary of doing it on Johnson’s terms. “The U.K. government has no coherent plan to end the Brexit chaos and a general election will not solve the crisis,” said Adam Price, leader of the Welsh party Plaid Cymru (Para 7-11). *

The question here is what will happen first. 
BJ is calling for a vote under the FTP Act next week on have a GE on 12 Dec. The EU has not yet officially replied to BJ's request to Extend A50. 
Its possible that the EU will not give its extension reply until after the vote for a GE next week.  Bj has also offered to revise his timetable for voting on the WAB to give MPs from the 28th Oct to 6th Nov to debate and pass it. This time table is a far shorter period that MPs want/need, but in order to hold a GE on 12th Dec, Parliament needed to be dissolved on the 6th Nov.  It seems very unlikely that MPs will give BJ the 2/3 majority for a GE under FTP Act next week or to agree to BJ's new WAB time table. By next week it will be too late to get a GE by 12 Dec via a vote of No Confidence (this takes 7 weeks) but a Short Bill (setting aside the FTP Act) could be tried as this could be passed by a simple majority. The problem for BJ is that he does not have a majority, so he would need to get some opposition MPs to vote with him. In theory the SNP and LibDems want a GE, but the SNP also wants a Referendum on Scottish Independence so I would guess it would not want to annoy Labour because it will need Labours votes in future. I am not sure what the LibDems and DUP would do, but I doubt the LibDems would want to help BJ. Its also unclear what the ex-Conservative MPs would do. They may be promised to be re-admitted to the party, but many of them are retiring and may not want to help BJ. Also  the Short Bill is amendable and things that BJ does not want could be added. My guess is that BJ could try the Short Bill route. But could probably not get it passed by 31st Oct as it would need to go through all the stages of a normal bill. So I am sticking to an extension happening first.

"Boris Johnson has abandoned his “do or die” pledge to leave the EU by 31 October and will ask MPs to back a pre-Christmas general election next week. The prime minister has written to Jeremy Corbyn, saying he will give parliament one last opportunity to scrutinise his withdrawal agreement bill and “get Brexit done”, by 6 November. But he will also table a motion under the Fixed-term Parliaments Act next Monday, asking for an early general election. It would then be voted on on Tuesday. Johnson had previously said he would wait for confirmation from the EU27 of the Brexit delay he reluctantly requested on Saturday, after MPs refused to fast-track his deal through parliament in time for the 31 October deadline." https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2019/oct/24/boris-johnson-to-ask-mps-to-back-pre-christmas-election

I am actually ready to go to 100% now. Feels surreal with this question.  The Johnson government reportedly won’t be calling for an election (for now).  [1] The ball is firmly in the EU court, and I am expecting an extension to be granted in the coming days. [1] https://edition.cnn.com/uk/live-news/brexit-boris-johnson-thursday-dle-intl/index.html

Assuming the EU Extends A50 (as is now expected) it will be very interesting when it will be extended to. Commentators are saying that some countries such as France want to short extension to allow BJ's WAB to be passed, other say that the extension will be until 31st Jan (as requested in the letter that BJ sent the EU).  I am sure that the EU wants to get Brexit resolved, but I don't see either a short extension or an extension to  31st Jan being very likely to resolve matters.  The WAB has so many problems, particularly with the section on NI, that I can't see it getting through parliament without a lot of amendments. Regarding NI any solution that does not involve the whole UK remaining in the EU Customs Union will mean either a border between NI and Ireland, or a border between NI and GB. Choosing either option will put peace in NI at risk as a border with Ireland will stir up the Nationalists, a border with GB will stir up the Unionists. Both Nationalists and Unionists are capable of violence. If the UK changes the WAB to stay in the EU Customs Union that presumably means more negotiations with the EU. If the EU extend A50 to 31st January to give time for a GE, I am not sure that MPs will vote for that to happen. Each of the ways that a GE could arise involve several weeks for campaigning, vote counting and than possibly negotiations between parties to form a new government. There is very little time get this done before Christmas/New Year. There are logistics problems having a GE in the lead up to Christmas (many of the usual polling stations may already to booked for festive events) and voters are less likely to turn out on cold, wet and dark December days, particularity older voters who tend to vote Conservative. I doubt that the public will want an election campaign over the Christmas period at all. If an election is not called until after New Year it could not be completed by 31st Jan.  A Public Vote might be added to the WAB, but this would require about 20 weeks to organize (and if BJ refused to do so, much longer.)    Obviously I am guessing, but if I was the EU I would  extend A50  for an indefinite period that included a break clause every three or six months so that when they are ready the UK could officially Leave the EU. If I were an MP I would press for a Public Vote as the only way to avoid being blamed for Brexit, which the majority of experts and voters believe will make them worse off. If the public still vote to Leave then MPs cannot be blamed (for the immediate consequences and  for the years of further negotiations that will be needed to get FTA's with the EU and other countries.) , if voters vote to Remain then Brexit would be cancelled and most people would be glad that its over (if in doubt check the Polls, most people think voting for Brexit was a mistake.) And MPs could tell any constituents who were upset that its not MPs fault, its the voters.

Bercow has stated "I don't give a flying flamingo about your forecast" [1] . Boris allegedly looking for a ditch to die in. After the previous jocular comment, let me note that apparently the  European parliament was originally planning to sit this Thursday (24 of October) to ratify the deal (had it passed the House of Commons). The next sitting of the EU parliament will be on 14 November, but this does not mean that they will grant the extension on 24. The most probable plan seems to be that they will wait till the last minute and then convoke an extraordinary session. [1] https://t.co/7nLQlraJ6y
[2] https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2019/oct/21/eu-would-agree-to-brexit-delay-says-german-minister

Using this as a guide: https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2019/oct/20/what-next-for-boris-johnson-brexit-deal-withdrawal-bill-vote. I assume after the PM tries to pass a meaningful vote, the Speaker, Mr. Bercow, will block such a motion, but also that, whether the govternment's motion is allowed or blocked, some form of Letwin will ensure that there is a high likelihood of an extension to Article 50. There are sound legal reasons for the EU extending article 50: Gina Miller in a legal paper pointed out – “the wording of article 50(3) presupposes that the European council take the decisive lead with the consent of the withdrawing member state”. Secondly, 'the EU has a legal duty to all its member states to ensure that any such withdrawal is not damaging to what article 13(1) of the treaty on European Union calls the “consistency, effectiveness and continuity of its policies and actions”, or to the principle spelled out in article 13(2): “Pursuant to the principle of sincere cooperation the EU and the member states shall, in full mutual respect, assist each other in carrying out the tasks which flow from the treaties.”' (https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2019/mar/03/gina-miller-eu-delay-brexit-no-deal). The economic consequences of a hard Brexit will be massive. Consequently, I believe that the EU will grant, if needed, an extension to article 50. As I write, Mr. Bercow is speaking (https://www.theguardian.com/politics/live/2019/oct/21/brexit-johnson-to-push-for-deal-as-labour-woos-rebel-tories-eu-extension-live-news) and has just blocked the government's motion. Given Labour's concerns over withdrawal agreement Mr. Johnson has negotiated, and the concerns of the DUP and others, and the vast chasm between the opposition and the government on matters related to a custom's union and a confirmatory referendum, the EU will likely have to grant an extension. In the least, there is so little time left to get on with it. There is no majority for a second referendum as things stand. Mr. Johnson cannot achieve Brexit without an election, but, as recent polling indicates, he is unlikely to win an election without Brexit (https://www.msn.com/en-gb/news/uknews/boris-johnson-will-only-win-a-general-election-if-brexit-is-delivered-by-31-october-poll-suggests/ar-AAICVfG), so his endgame is Brexit, deal or no deal. This comment is not a forecast.
What I think should happen with this badly conceived Brexit process it that a WA should be aproved, then a fully defined Future Trading Relationship (FTR) should be agreed. Then a public vote of on the WA and the FTR. Then (if the public agreed) an implementation period started. 
This is more or less what the sequence that was supposed be. All I have added is the Public Vote and that what was called the Future Framework is worked up into a legal text. The reason for adding the Public Vote is that the 2016 referendum was a vote to change the UK relationship to the EU, without clarity on what relationship the public wanted. The reason for making the FTR a legal document is that without legal certainty the public can't be sure where the UK relationship will finish up.  (With BJ as PM many are suspicious that the FTA will not be agreed because many Conservative Breiteers prefer what the Brexit Party wants, and the BJ deal is just a means of getting there.) The reason for starting the implementation period after both the WA and FTR become law, is that until the final destination has being agreed its not possible to start implementing it.   For example if the final FTR needs specific technological solutions and has staffing training and recruitment implications for governments and businesses, "implementing"  can't be done before you know what these are, and probably can't even be planned for until you know what they are. I am not expecting this to happen because it seems there is less political interest in successful outcomes than in taking bold leaps into the dark. The list of screwed up projects that the UK has started in the last few decades that have spectacularly failed because of the urge to "do something bold" without first working out if the project could ever work or the details and cost of doing it.  Example include lots of computer systems such as those for the NHS that cost billions before being scrapped, railway project that were started, stopped, restarted and stopped again, that were either not completed and/or way over budget. Universal Credit; a good idea that was not thought through, and was badly designed. Heathrow airport expansion never started because (like Brexit) is contradicts itself (any expansion will increase pollution in a heavily populated area.)   Joining in many wars in the middle east with no clear idea of what they were supposed to achieve, let alone a plan for achieving anything. So the Government claims to think that the EU would do itself a lot of harm rather than delay Brexit for 3 months. After the time wasted by the UK so far what does another few months matter? Probably everything reduces to Super Saturday vote, which might very well turn out to be Doomsday Saturday for BJ. The first problem to sort out is how many votes are really a sure "yes" or "no" vote for the deal. They vary according to different sources and I find myself having no clear idea of how many Tory and Labour potential rebels there are, which means that my numbers are not expected to be accurate, but mostly a ballpark estimate. For the probable outcome of the vote, I will use [1], which seems to be a good source. For the "moving parts" of the vote, I will use this twitter post [2]. From [1] a base case scenario is: 318 yes, 321 no Now we remove the "moving parts" of the voting process: this include 21 Tory rebels (or maybe 22-23, actually it's not that important) from the yes, 10 DUP MPs from the no, 25 Tory MPs from the ERG (again, sometimes they are counted as 28) from the yes, and 22 moving-piece Labour MP's ([1] counts 7 as yes, 15 as no). Outcome: 265 yes, 295 no And now comes the probability calculation, the most important piece: (i) the crucial factor (as we will see) is the DUP, whether they will really vote against at the end (ii) for the Tory rebels, I will assume they will vote individually and give each of them a 90% of  probability of voting for the deal (according to Oliver Letwin [3]). This gives us a binomial voting distribution. (iii) for the Labor "swingers", I will also assume that they will vote individually (probably incorrect, but also probably irrelevant), with a 0.3 probability of voting for the deal. The binomial distribution peaks at 6 yes votes, which 5 and 7 also probable, while smaller and bigger number of "yes" votes increasingly improbable. Actually they will be whipped, but the outcome is expected to be similar. (iv) the ERG is the most interesting piece: they vowed to vote with the DUP, but they are having doubts [4]. Two scenarios them: (iv.a) if DUP votes against, I will give the individual ERG MP will have a 30% probability of voting against and a 70% probability of voting for (I'm betting on them breaking their previous vow). Again, a binomial distribution. (iv.b) if DUP votes for, they will all vote for. With this, after crunching a few numbers, the outcome is that if the DUP votes yes the deal is approved 99.15% of the times, if the DUP votes no the deal is rejected 99.83% of the times. In short: DUP is the freaking key for the deal to pass The DUP has stated and restated that they will not vote for the deal. But they could change their minds, as this is politics. Let's say 25%. Now, if the voting fail, there is a change of a vote of no confidence, followed by a chance success of that vote, followed by a change of success of a new election, followed by a change that the date for a new election will happen before the extension is granted. We fermi it: P(GE) = P(vote of no confidence) x P(goes through) x P(set a date GE) x P(if GE, it is set before the extension is granted) I will rule out the possibility of the EU negating the extension. Not knowing how to estimate the said probabilities, I will give a 50% chance each, which gives a total of 1/16 (6.25%) of a date for a new GE set before the EU grants an extension. This is compounded of course with the base 75% probability of the vote failing, yielding a 4.7%. The rest of the probability (70%) goes to extension. Note: try to improve the estimation of the probability of the DUP changing its vote. P.S. There is a second outside view, based on how many votes has BJ won in the house of commons. From memory it seems that it has been 1 of 8, giving a 12.5% for BJ to pass the deal. Seems to be on the same ballpark than the 25% I am conceding to him. On the other hand he might try really hard, and the probability could be as high as 40 or 50%. UPDATE: I have been tinkering with the probabilities above. A few results: 1) If I made the ERG completely thrash out their vow to the DUP and vote for the deal, that will give a 6% pass probability if the DUP says no. So final probability: P_PASS = P_DUP + (1-P_DUP)*0.05 = 0.295 for P_DUP = 0.25. 2) If I reduce the probability of the Tory rebels to vote for from 0.9 to 0.8, then the probability of the deal not passing even if the DUP says yes will be 0.08 (8%). This will require a correction of the type P_PASS = P_DUP * (1 - 0.08) = 0.23 or 23% for a base probability of 25%. 3) Combining both scenarios I would arrive at a 27-28%. 4) One can play other games like modifying the voting probability for the maximum of 22 Labour that could change their votes, but we end up with the same type of bands. 5) The exception might be in the extreme cases, e.g. I make all the ERG vote for, and increase the probability of Labour "rebels" voting for to 0.4 (i.e. assuming between 8 and 10 Labour voting for), then I end up with a 22% probability of passing. 6) The point is again that the bulk of the probability comes down to the DUP changing its current stance, maybe corrected by factor ranging from 0.8 to 1.2 (probably not important), with the biggest corrections happening if their probability of no changing their stance is zero, [1] https://www.ft.com/content/c0c6298c-f0e6-11e9-bfa4-b25f11f42901
[2] https://twitter.com/GoodwinMJ/status/1184842110626869248/photo/1?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw%7Ctwcamp%5Etweetembed%7Ctwterm%5E1184842110626869248
[3] https://inews.co.uk/news/politics/brexit/purged-tory-grandees-preparing-to-back-boris-johnsons-brexit-deal-816352
[4] https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2019/oct/17/its-painful-to-choose-erg-locked-in-internal-talks-over-brexit-deal

There is a court hearing today in Scotland on the legality of the WA deal. The same people who got the prorogation of Parliament ruled illegal are saying that having NI apply EU customs is in conflict with a UK law.
Under the current law, Section 55 of the Taxation (Cross-border Trade) Act 2018 prevents Northern Ireland from having difference customs rules than the rest of the UK. 
Presumably BJ would need to first change that act before agreeing the WA.
The same court case raises some other objections (e.g. MPs need the full legal text of WA before voting on it).
This could delay agreeing the WA. If the WA is delayed after Saturday of any reason BJ needs to ask for an Extension, but the EU does not need to grant it immediately or at all. So the Scottish legal action will probably not have any affect on the outcome of this question. (I will reduce my forecast a little) Another legal issue that does not (yet) seem to have come to court must surely be the consent of NI. On the face of it (to a non lawyer) the WA as it applies to NI must be a change that requires the consent of the NI Assembly before it starts, not confirmation of consent several years afterwards. If a court ruled that the NI Assembly needed to vote for the WA NI provisions that would present a major problem. The NI Assembly is not sitting, most parties in NI are against Brexit, the DUP is (or has been) pro-Brexit but is against BJ's WA deal. (I will reduce my forecast by another 5% due to this.)

It is worth making sure that the wording of the question is followed when considering the answers. For the article 50 period to be extended the EU27 have to agree. 
Irrespective of any request being made there will need to be an agreement on what the extension of the agreement is for, be that a general election, a referendum or a further negotiating period for the withdrawal agreement. In that case the UK will need to set dates for a referendum or a GE and this would likely need to be agreed prior to the approval for the extension. There has been some discussion around the period needed for the UK parliament to agree the current WA as it will be a very large piece of legislation - however it appears that the current negotiations are being made around the pre-existing agreement with the exception of the Irish backstop portion. As such the agreement could be passed quite quickly given that the majority of the agreement has already been reviewed over a long period of parliamentary time.

The DUP has said this morning they will not vote for this WA. Maybe they will change their minds, but if the WA is as described in the media it would create a big problem for the DUP.
It might be thought that as the DUP is a party in favour of Brexit it would be keen to agree BJ's deal, but that ignores what the point of the DUP is. Without going back into Irish history its necessary to understand what the DUP's raison d'etre is. Its underlying purpose was to stop what their supporters saw as the risk of  Irish Protestants being overwhelmed by Irish Catholics. The Protestants saw themselves as British, the Catholics were seen as Irish Popests. Before the 1960s the NI Protestants controlled the NI government, police and business, but the 1960s saw the rise of protest movements in many countries where communities who felt they were being denied civil rights started agitating for their civil rights. When you increase the civil rights of one group the previously dominant group if usually not happy. 
So the DUP raison d'etre is to stop NI becoming like Ireland. The Good Friday Agreement recognized this and gave both the Protestants and Catholics vetos on changes. 
As far as I can understand the issue with the BJ WA is what exactly "a change" is. Most people in NI would see "a change" as being something that alters the current arrangement between NI and Ireland. The DUP sees "a change" as something that alters the current arrangement between NI and GB. Logically if GB itself changes (by not being in the EU and having some as yet unknown trading relationship) but NI remains aligned with Ireland and the EU, then a future change in NI to remove this alignment with the EU, this change ought to be agreed by both communities. 
As the majority of voters in NI were not in favour of Brexit, it seems unlikely that there would be cross community consensus for NI to change what (I assume) is in the BJ WA. So the DUP would see NI's economy becoming more integrated with Ireland's and less like GB's. The inconvenience of the paper work and duties paid and maybe refunded required for NI/GB trade compared to frictionless trade between NI and Ireland (and the EU) would be certain to gradually mean NI become more like Ireland (and probable eventually lead to a united Ireland. 
So for the DUP the long term affect of voting for BJ's WA could make the party irrelevant.

As the public and most MPs (and possibly no EU 27 Governments) have not yet seen a clear outline of what is being negotiated, let alone seen a legal text and the Benn Act sets a deadline of 19th Oct before the PM has to ask for an Extention to A50 it seems very likely that A50 would have to be extended before the UK can Leave the EU with a Deal in Place. 
The Benn Act requires not just that the UK agrees in principal to a WA, but that "a Deal" has been voted thru the UK Parliament. As the deal between Mrs May and EU ran to over 600 pages, (and was very difficult to read because lots of sections required that the reader read other legal documents in order to understand variations to them that the WA would entail). I can't see MPs voting on such an important document that they (or their legal advisors) have not had time to read, and that they have not had time to discuss with their constituents, by 19th Oct. 
Its possible that if BJ requests an Extension to A50 as required by the Benn Act, that the EU could delay replying to the request until they have a clear idea what the UK would use the extension for. For example they might delay replying in order to see if the UK Parliament will vote for it before the 31st Oct. If the extension had been requested but the UK Parliament then voted thru a WA, then the Extension would (probably) not happen. Given that having the UK agree a WA was supposed to happen six months before the Leaving Date it seems quite possible that the EU side will require more that two weeks to study the legal text (I am assuming that the EU 27 have some idea what Barnier might agree to, but don't have a legal text.) Some in Germany have spoken of needing an extension of two months in order to ensure the legal document is acceptable to them.    How likely it is that the UK Parliament would approve the WA is very difficult to know. From media reports it seems that BJ has offered things that the DUP has previously said were unacceptable so they may not support it, and some other Conservative MPs may not support it for the same reasons. The Conservatives are well short of a majority in Parliament (about 40 votes short) so they will need quite a few other MPs to support them. How many of the 21 MPs that BJ expelled from the Conservative Party would vote for the deal? I don't know. Some Labour MPs might vote for a deal. But I suspect that the ex-Conservative MPs and any Labour MPs who voted a a deal would only do so if Brexit was conditional of a new Public vote (obviously that would require an extension to A50, which would have to be granted before a date for referendum could be set.)     If MPs decided they did not like Bj's deal (as the opposition is almost certain to do) then they could try and kick out BJ. If they can't agree first to replace BJ with someone other than Corbyn I don't see the opposition kicking out BJ. If they did kick out BJ and get an new PM the new PM would have to get an extension to A50 before either a GE or a referendum. If BJ lost a non-confidence vote after 19th Oct if the outcome was either a new PM or a GE the extension to A50 would presumably have to take place under the Benn Act.  As the rules are that Parliament has two weeks to find a replacement PM before a GE would be called, if the two week period started after tomorrow, then it would last until after the 31st Oct. So a GE being called before 31st Oct could really only happen if 2/3rds of MPs voted for it, which seems very unlikely. Then there is the question of will a WA be agreed at all this week. 
Its all very uncertain. My Forecast of 100% extension is less that I am certain that it will happen, than the chances of any of the other options being so small that I can't put a number on them.
I find it very difficult to believe that the new deal they are discussing will pass the EU27 nor parliament, nevertheless, there seems a chance.

BJ and Varadkar say they can see a pathway to a deal. 
There are suggestions that the changes are connected to customs and the process of agreeing to discontinue any arrangements.  
Assuming that the red lines can be moved and they have found a pathway to a deal there are four possibilities (at least!). It could be (as some reports suggest) that BJ has dropped all the red lines are just wants a deal. And that he has dropped the "cake and eat it" approach. A deal along the lines of Norway + staying in the EU Customs Union could (possibly) be agreed in a few days, although it sounds unlikely. It could also possibly be agreed by the UK Parliament, not with votes of the hard Brexiteers, but with votes from soft Brexit Conservative and Labour MPs. It seems possible but unlikely as Labour is now talking about agreeing a WA deal conditional on another referendum.   A more likely possibility is that NI remains in a Customs Union with the EU and follows EU rules (so a  Norway + for just NI) while GB (UK minus NI) leaves the EU CU and rules, and the border is between  NI and the GB (and between GB and EU). The hard Brexiteers may agree to this, but I am not sure that a majority of MPs would. Those two possibilities are fairly clear and easy to understand and could maybe to turned in an agreed deal in 20 days. But getting parliament to pass it seems very unlikely.  The another perhaps more likely possibility is that BJ is suggesting a totally new approach (it was reported his idea was to get the Future Trade outine agreed before the WA). If this is what BJ wants I can't see it being done without extending A50 by some considerable time.  Its also possible that BJ and/or Varadkar are just spinning the process out and trying to blame the other, and the path does not exist. The referendum idea seems to be gaining momentum. Tony Blair has said a referendum would not need to take the 22 weeks previously suggested, because the 22 weeks included 12 weeks to pass legislation. So a referendum could be carried out in three months or so. But that would also require extending A50.

Many commentators are suggesting this week's change to the WA proposed by BJ is not really a serious attempt to agree a withdrawal deal with the EU, but an exercise in getting the excuses ready as to why the UK will not leave the EU on 31st October. The reason for having the excuses ready are so that BJ can claim that its not his fault for failing to leave the EU but the EU's/Parliament's/Soft Brexiteers/Hard Brexiteers/Ireland/Labour etc. BJ will need to blame someone when the next GE takes place. 
The folks he is going to try to blame for his failure know what BJ is trying to so, and so they are in turn each tying to blame some other group. Therefore rather than just reject BJ's proposal they are all pretending that they are taking it seriously.   But lets join the game and pretend BJ is serious about his proposal and give it consideration.  
For some reason BJ has published only a description of his proposal not the legal text. What has been described sounds complex, but I suspect putting this in a watertight legal text will be very complex. Exactly how do you define the EU rules that NI would need to obey in order to have goods (including foods) conform to EU standards? Would those who produce the goods need to conform to EU employment law? Would NI have to conform to EU environmental laws? Would a business in NI be able to sell goods to any EU country and include a service contract? Would a NI service provider be able to operate in the EU? Would it be able to if it sold a product that was both a goods and service? 
If the NI Assembly remains out of action (as it has been since March 2017) how would it be able to agree in the next 4 weeks that it would not block the BJ NI deal at the end of the implementation period? If it did block the BJ deal (which it could do if even one party in the Assembly wanted to) the EU and Ireland would appear to have signed a deal that would be never implemented. If NI remains under some EU rules what is the legal process to deal with disputes? Does the ECJ still try NI dispute cases. 
How exactly would the new NI customs system work, which checks would not be done at the customers premises? What would happen when the customer is not in NI (for instance a freight shipment to/from Scotland.)
How/Where would the checks that goods from Britain (UK excluding NI) to NI be carried out to ensure that they conformed with EU rules (at the ports in NI? on ferries? at the ports in Britain?) Would the EU trust a 3rd country (the UK) to carry out these checks on its behalf? It sound to me that getting a fully watertight agreement would take a big team a lawyers months to draw up. 
Then the EU Parliament would need to agree the deal, and each Parliament in each EU country, as well as the EU Commission and UK Parliament (and NI Assembly). Originally the EU/UK timetable allowed for 12 months to prepare the WA legal text and 6 months for ratification. BJ insists in must be done in 28 days. He has repeatedly said that he will not extend the deadline by even a few days, if the deal is not complete by 31st Oct the UK will walkout with No Deal. Of course you may not believe him (I don't) but when someone insists that something has to be done by a particular date for no real reason, when it involves agreeing complex details, I assume I am dealing with someone who is afraid that the flaws is in the deal will became clear if too much time is spent looking at it. I am sure this is the case with this deal. So I am sure the EU will not agree to it., but if they did it would take more time and A50 would need to be extended. For UK MPs those who today say they would vote for the BJ proposal are in many cases also saying that BJ needs to make further changes to WA. My guess is that they are hoping that the EU reject the deal before they are called on to vote in Parliament.  Clearly Corbyn's plan is to force BJ to fail to deliver a deal before November, as a GE after that date would see BJ's Conservatives as Brexit failures opposed by the Brexit Party, both fighting for the Pro-Brexit vote.  The polls show that only 40% of voters think that leaving the EU is a good idea and the majority think another referendum is needed.      But I am sure A50 will need to extended first.

Whoops.  I made a clear error in my reasoning.  The government may try to circumvent the Benn Act--they are insistent they won't be stopped from leaving 31 October. https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2019/sep/27/benn-act-is-watertight-gauke-deems-majors-brexit-fears-misplaced  But it won't become moot, will it, in the event that Parliament approves Johnson's 'new deal'?  In fact, it requires him to make the request by 19 October.  He could try, I suppose, if they seem to be getting close to a deal, to gather enough votes to undo the Benn Act, to buy more time.  But the majority who fear a crash-out wouldn't fall for that, would they?  So Johnson has his hands tied by the Benn Act, and Ireland against his new proposal ... . So even if he gets the deal approved by Parliament, he can't be confident.

I'm now thinking the odds of Johnson getting his new deal through parliament have jumped up to better than even, now that he has the DUP on board.  He needs 319 votes.  Assuming he's starting at 287 (https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2019/sep/16/johnson-will-need-labour-mps-to-vote-for-any-brexit-agreement), they get him to 297, with exactly 50 possible supporters across the three major parties: 29 Tories, 20 Labour, and 1 Lib Dem.  Assuming he can bring along just 15 of his own party members, can he get 5 more?  Or can he get the whole 22 from the Conservatives, including a couple of ERG members?  That seems very possible, if far from assured.  So I will put it at 52%.   Bringing us to the EU side.  Ireland may yet veto the UK government's new proposal, and their language is pretty strong against it.  The deal would require unanimity, wouldn't it?  And presumably most of Europe would defer to Ireland anyway.  But if Johnson can get parliamentary approval for his deal, that makes the Benn Act moot, and so the EU will be playing chicken with a Johnson government clearly happy to crash out.  So rejecting the deal would mean a crash out.  So maybe something less than even odds the E.U. would accept the new offer?  45%?  So 45% of 52% gives us 23.4%.  But I think I will tweak that upward to 25%.   And with the time remaining, and the government so steadfastly asserting they WILL NOT request an extension (Jacob Rees Mogg signaling their legal position--that Article 50 trumps the Benn Act--the possibility of a 'crash out' now seems higher than it was yesterday as well.  The option that an election date will be set before an extension or an agreement now seems less likely.  And I'll keep the outside possibility that the May agreement will be the fallback as a 1% option, even if it's hard to imagine the scenario where that happens.

There's talk of a motion of no confidence being raised, which would allow parliament to elect a caretaker PM, these discussions would not be taking place unless some kind of agreement had been reached among those aligned against the Conservative government. The SNP and labour seem to have come to an agreement on that and if all party members voted in favour it would give them 282 votes...  This of course would not be enough, but the paranoia of Boris Johnson being willing to do whatever it takes to leave the EU has evidently set in and instead of waiting around these parties seem to be increasingly willing to respond.  Another thing to consider is that Boris Johnson used tactical voting in order to secure his position as PM, the votes were engineered in such a way that made Jeremy Hunt the 2nd place candidate over Michael Gove in the Conservative leadership contest, this was done because his campaign deemed JH to be less appealing to conservative party voters and therefore less of a threat. It's not impossible for BJ to use the same tactic in order to trigger a vote of no confidence, with a view to set a date for a general election after leaving. On the flip side if the Vote of no confidence is triggered and the opposition parties cannot agree on a caretaker PM, the conservatives would be able to set a GE date for post Brexit, resulting in either a rehashed deal being brokered or a hard Brexit... From the Economist 
“Has a party with no MPs ever wielded such influence at Westminster? Nigel Farage’s Brexit Party, which ends a week of conference-style events today in London, is under a year old and is polling in the teens. If, as expected, Britain holds an election later this year, it will not win many seats. Yet it could easily determine the outcome. Mr Farage’s ultra-hard line on Brexit (he says “no deal” is the only acceptable outcome) is enough to tempt some voters away from the Tories. If Britain’s exit is delayed again next month, as seems likely, still more will defect, potentially costing the Tories the marginal seats needed for a majority. The need to out-Farage Mr Farage helps explain both why the Tories chose Boris Johnson as their leader and why Mr Johnson is using an ever-more populist tone. The Brexit Party may be going nowhere, but it has pushed the country in a worrying direction.“

“Britain’s MPs return to Parliament today after a landmark legal judgment went against Boris Johnson’s government on September 24th. I have updated to account for the chicken game being played between the EU and the UK. Though the threat is more credible from the EU than from the UK, it is still against the EU interest to allow a no deal brexit. Even if it is true that the extension has to be granted by unanimity, it would be unwise for France to go ahead despite the probable objections of other countries, as this could easily lead to escalation and a rise of anti-EU populism. On the other hand, these brinkmanship tactics might very well indicate that a new agreement is underway, not necessarily on time (if it happens on time it will give a signal that Johnson is weak, while if a deal is promised to be underway the EU can still argue that their strategy worked). I will give it a 20% probability of happen, and only a 50% probability of being accepted if it happens, adding 10 points to "new deal brexit" and 10 point to "no deal brexit", which is probably too far-fetched as this assumes the EU is serious with the chicken game.

Following the expulsion of 21 MPs from the Conservative Party, the government no longer has the numbers even in theory to get a deal through Parliament. Paradoxically, this has weakened the position of the DUP, which no longer holds the balance of power. Boris Johnson's attempts to negotiate a new deal have not been received warmly in Brussels, which has no confidence that any deal can now make it through Parliament. Meanwhile, the opposition parties are determined to keep the Conservatives in government until November, having passed a law requiring the government to seek a Brexit extension. This means that Johnson's options are likely to be a) no-deal Brexit (now illegal); b) seek an extension (political suicide in the forthcoming election); or c) resignation (a humiliating end to his political career). I suspect that, as a natural risk-taker, he may well opt for a no-deal Brexit, at which point it will be up to the Conservative Parliamentary Party to decide quickly whether to demand his resignation in the knowledge that it would likely destroy their electoral prospects, or be complicit in breaking the law. The slightly higher probability I have given to no-deal Brexit reflects the fact that those MPs most likely to oppose Johnson are no longer members of his party.

Current opinion based on recent events and my appreciation of potential options by key participants.

Now Parliament has been prorogued they cannot make any decisions until they return on 14 Oct.  Negotiations with the EU will continue in the meantime.  So it is possible that a new or amended WA agreed by the UK negotiators and the EU might be ready when Parliament returns.  The only action that I can see that can possibly occur in the absence of Parliament is the extension, as this does not require parliament to do anything further if the extension given by the EU is until the end of January.    However, this would require BJ to ask for one before he absolutely has to, which is very unlikely given his opposition to asking for an extension.  So it is very unlikely that anything will change or be resolved until Parliament starts its new session on 14 Oct.   The first day or two will include the Queen's speech, and the Government setting out its business for the new parliamentary session so there will not be a lot of time to discuss Brexit.  If a new or amended WA is on the table. then I can see BJ may wish to ask the MPs to vote on it in the first few days as if it passed then BJ would not need to ask the EU for an extension.  Now that the DUP is no longer able to prop up the Government as the two parties combined are now in a minority, it may be possible to reintroduce the idea of Northern Ireland being part of the Customs Union so that trade can freely flow between the North and the South and effectively put the border in the Irish Sea between Ireland and GB.  Although this is not acceptable to the DUP it might not meet significant resistance from the English, Scottish and Welsh MPs across all parties.  This would also remove the need for the backstop, which is the main element which prevented TM's WA from succeeding.  If no new or amended deal is on the table, then BJ may ask the MPs to vote for TM's WA.  Although this was previously rejected there is a chance that it may pass this time, as it would probably be more palatable to BJ to leave in accordance with the WA than to ask for an extension and he could whip his MPs to vote for it under threat of deselection, meaning even the ERG may vote for it this time.  There would probably also be enough Labour MPs that would vote for it to allow it to pass. Once a (new or old) WA has been passed by Parliament, there would be no need to ask for an extension. I think that there is a fair chance that a (new or old) WA will be voted on before 19 Oct.  If it passes, then the question will resolve once the UK leaves the EU on the Terms of the WA.  But it could still be possible that Parliament passes a WA and then sets a date for a GE between the date of passing the WA and actually leaving, which would cause the question to resolve in favour of a GE.  So we cannot discount this option yet.  It is very unlikely that there will be enough support for a GE until either an extension has definitely been obtained or a WA is passed. If no WA is agreed by 19 Oct, then BJ will have to ask for an extension.  Assuming that the EU agree (and I can't see them not agreeing as they are keen to avoid a no-deal exit), the question would then resolve in this way.   A no-deal exit is looking pretty unlikely on 31 Oct at this stage. So it seems as if an extension, leaving with a WA (old or new) or setting a date for a GE are the possible outcomes.

All-in on 'extend' because having broken down all the routes I can think of for Boris to avoid an extension, I can't see how any of them can succeed. The options for Boris are limited. In order to avoid an extension to the 31 October brexit date he can either; • Find and use a loophole in the Benn bill. (This is the government's current plan [1].)
• Find an EU country to block an extension. (The most promising candidate - France - will not help [2].)
• Refuse to comply with the Benn bill. (The govt. is now saying the PM must obey the law - durr.)
• Get Theresa May's deal through parliament. (It was defeated by a majority of 149 last time.)
• Get a new or renegotiated deal through parliament. (The Commons will block any deal.)
• Resign. (This would result in an extension anyway.) The government's plan is to test the legal limits of the Benn bill designed to force Boris to request an extension, but I think the government is doing this not in order to leave without a deal but to get a better deal from the EU. However even if the government's lawyers succeed in circumventing the bill, the EU is not daft - they know that all they have to do is refuse to budge then sit back and watch the chaos. Finding a way round the bill just isn't a realistic plan politically, even if it is successful legally. [1] https://metro.co.uk/2019/09/08/boris-johnson-will-test-law-to-block-no-deal-to-the-limit-10706367/
[2] https://twitter.com/Mij_Europe/status/1170675088406077440

The following comments are not strictly related to this question, but are relevant to what happens after 31st Oct. The latest polls on which party people would vote for in a GE show why BJ want to hold one now, and why besides stopping BJ from using the election process to stop the UK falling out of the EU, the other parties would prefer to wait until November The polls that specifically asked about voting intentions if the GE was before 1st Nov or after 31st Oct and the UK had not left the EU. If the GE was before 1st Nov the Conservatives would get the highest percentage of votes, if the GE was held after 31st Oct and the UK had not left the EU then either Conservative and Lobour would get an equal percentage of votes or Labour would get the highest percentage of votes. The Brexit Party would gain several percentage points if the UK has not left the EU by 1st Nov. The combined percentage  of the Conservative plus Brexit Party remains fairly constant no Brexit moves votes from the Conservatives to the Brexit Party.  An issue with the polling method is that some polls present the party choices differently. They offer some named Parties and "other" but the parties that are named are not the same in all polls. If "other" is selected the person being polled is then offered other Parties as options. From looking at the results any party that is one "named" will get more people chose it than if the person polled has to first select "other" and then choose from the smaller Parties. The biggest effect of this seems to be on the percentage of people who choose The Brexit Party. I understand that in some polls the Brexit Party is a first level option and on others its a in a sub-list within "other". I suspect (but I don't have the time or means to confirm) that the highest percentages for the Conservatives are when the Brexit Party in part of the "other" option.  For example the latest YouGove poll has the Conservatives on 35%, but it only lists Cons, Lab, LibDem and Brexit, while other polls have 10% of more of voters planning to vote for other parties. As some of these "other" parties such as the SNP will get high percentages in a region, and are likely to get a lot more seats that the Brexit Party or the LibDems the poll is misleading.  My conclusion (and that of the polling companies) is that when ever a GE is held the result is likely to be hung parliament, and if held after 31st Oct without Brexit happening it will probably be a hung parliament. My second comment is rather broader.
As the Brexit crisis has developed UK politics has changed more than it has in decades. We have been told that "the will of the people" is true democracy and that representative democracy is not. We have been told that MPs must vote for what "the people want". That MPs must vote for what the Leader of their Party tells them to. That Parliament must vote for what "the people want" even if their constituents do not want that. That Judges must take account of what "the people want" when ruling on legal disputes. Parliament can talk, but not set policy, that a job for the PM and his advisors. like children MPs should be seen and not heard.  In the last few weeks we have had Parliament being prorogued because, according to the PM having it sitting is inconvenient for the executive. We have had MPs kicked out of the ruling Party because the PM is sovereign and members of his party who disagree with him are inconvenient. Spending time coming up with policies that MPs will agree with wastes time, Arguing to find better policies is also a waste of time. 
We are told that the PM does not need to obey the law if it contradicts what "the people want". And the only person who knows "the will of the people" is the PM.  We now hear that its very inconvenient have a Speaker in the Commons who does not toe the Government line. The old convention that when elected Speaker the holder ceased being a party representative and was therefore elected in his constituency unopposed.  So because the Speaker who was a Conservative has not given some Conservative MPs their own way, rather than allow Parliament to select its own Speaker, the Government will attempt to put up another Conservative candidate in his constituency so that the current Speaker  will cease to be an MP.
I would not be surprised if the new Conservative Populist Party did not do what many Populist Government do and grab hold of the process of choosing the Supreme Court Judges.  After all the UK Supreme Court only dates back to 2009 (before that the Law Lords in the House of Lords had a similar role). It should easy enough to have the judges appointed by the PM. With no codified constitution, and with "convention" being thrown out the UK is in great danger of having an elected dictator as PM, who controls the executive, the legislation, and justice. Voters in other countries have allowed this to happen on many occasions. Cries for a decisive leader are answered by a strongman, who when crossed becomes a tyrant.

In this bright new world BJ would be sovereign. I doubt that "the people" will let him. So my forecast is that if BJ is not kicked out in the next few months the UK will be stuck a with him. Because there will be no effective parliament "the people" will take to the streets much as they have in Hong Kong.  So the Brexiteers were right and the UK will have become like the countries of the far east. Like Singapore where you have complete political freedom as long as you vote for the one party or Hong Kong where you have to give up all your political rights.  I hope the UK goes back to being a country of reason. I think it will but it will not be the same it will need a proper codified constitution.

So Boris now says he would rather be dead in a ditch than ask the EU for an extension.  He has repeatedly said that the UK is leaving on 31 Oct "do or die".  But a law is due to be passed on Monday which will force him to ask for an extension if there is no deal agreed by 19 Oct.  He's in a tricky situation now. What will he do? Break the law or backtrack and ask for an extension? Or try to find a way out?  He's a slippery politician and the way out route might seem the best face-saving option to him.  He could resign, but I don't think he's ready to move out of Downing St just yet. Holding a GE is another way out, but requires the other parties to agree to one.  They don't trust him and are likely to refuse until they have a Brexit extension in the bag unless the date of the election is guaranteed, which is not the case under Monday's motion, as the PM can choose the date of a GE.  Another way out would be to have a deal  agreed by 19 Oct. But time is running out for negotiating a new deal or even amending the old one.  So will he try to push TM's deal through in the new Parliamentary session before 19 Oct, possibly whilst claiming that he couldn't force the EU to give the UK a better deal because his negotiating strength had been curtailed by the threat of no-deal being taken off the table? He would then have managed to take the UK out of the EU by 31 Oct as he promised and could blame the Tory rebels and Labour for his failure to provide a better deal or indeed a no deal exit. That would probably allow him to keep his pro-Brexit supporter base and put him in a reasonably good position for contesting a GE. But how would parliament vote on the WA?  Would they be relieved that a no deal exit had been averted and take the WA this time? Or would they push for an extension then a GE in the hope of ousting Boris and installing a more pro-EU government? Could be a risky gamble.  Accordingly I'm increasing odds on leaving with a WA. Let's see what happens on Monday...

Details of a Bill which aims to prevent the UK from leaving the EU without an agreement have been revealed. The European Union (Withdrawal) (no 6) Bill will be presented to Parliament by Labour former minister Hilary Benn. Shadow Brexit secretary Keir Starmer said the Bill could be Parliament's "last chance" to stop a "reckless and damaging" no-deal Brexit. The Bill requires the Government to either reach a deal with the EU, or gain Parliament's approval for a no-deal exit by October 19. If the Government has not met one of these conditions by the deadline, it will be require to write to the European Union seeking an extension, until January 31, 2020. It is thought that the purpose of the extension would be to provide the Government with sufficient time to carry out a "genuine and sincere negotiation", and to provide time to ratify any deal that is secured. It will also give time to allow Parliament to seek to build a consensus on the way forward.

@Anneinak has summarized  very well the situation, so I will not repeat it all. Lord Lisvane, former Clerk of the House of Commons, who is obviously an expert on the process of passing legislation was interviewed last night. The view was that given yesterday's commons defeat for the Government the bill to prevent a No Deal brexit should get through the Commons today. A specific process in the House of Lords would be used that should see it passed on Friday. All this assumes that there is a majority for the bill at every step, but that seems likely because the Government now has no majority in either the Commons or Lords. It should have a majority in the Commons similar to last nights vote (i.e. around 27) and much bigger majority in the Lords. BJ has said he does not want a GE, but he is going to try and get the Commons to Vote for one under the FTP Act on Thursday. (I assume BJ does not expect anyone to believe a word he says, or think that it matters) This would require Conservative and Labour MPs to vote for it. Labour and the other opposition parties say they will not vote for a GE until they can be certain that their bill to stop a NO Deal brexit has become law.  As the bill to Stop a No Deal Brexit is unlikely be become law (assuming it passes) until next Monday BJ will not have much time to get MPs to vote for a GE before Parliament is prorogued. The order for Prorogation says that the earliest Parliament will be prorogued will be Monday 9th Sep and the latest will be Thursday 12th Sep.   As BJ is not trusted I would expect the opposition would not vote for the GE as soon as the bill to Stop No Deal is passed, but require that the date of the GE was guaranteed. The FTP Act does not allow amendment to be added, so it can't used to set guarantees or conditions. To have these another bill would first need to be passed  setting aside the FTP Act. Then another amendable bill could be passed guaranteeing the date of the GE, but the opposition could also add any other conditions such as a having a second referendum (aka Public Vote on Brexit). If BJ won a subsequent GE with a majority a new Government could overturn that, but it would show the public how this endless Brexit shambles could be ended (A No Deal would just be ending step one of Brexit and be followed by years or decades trying to get new deals.) If I was Corbyn I would not trust BJ to actually extend A50. The No Deal bill would not require BJ to seek an extension until after 19th Oct (if parliament has not passed an WA). BJ has said he would obey the law, but he has also said there is no way he will go to the EU to ask for an A50 Extension. (I guess one of these statements is true, but maybe neither is true.) Who knows what BJ will do. So using the excuse that as Parliament is being prorogued there is no time to get the FTPA set aside and get a a GE date agreed it make more sense to talk about a GE after 19th Oct and after BJ has got A50 extended. I would have thought that this would give Corbyn some tactic advantage regarding the subsequent GE. A GE held in November would show that BJs ridiculous "do or die Brexit by 31st Oct" was just hot air, that (probably) he has not negotiated a new WA by 31st Oct, the Conservative Party would be completely split between the Populist wing and the traditional wing. The longer he is PM the more mistakes BJ (and Cummings) are likely to make. We saw how Mrs May blew her chances at the 2017 GE, Cummings could do the same for BJ. Of course there are still the court cases that could mean the Prorogation has to be changed. Its not really relevant to this forecast, but BJ/Cummings/Rees-Mogg seem to be going out of their way to ensure no one from the centrist Conservatives would want to vote Conservative. RM acting like a cartoon version of the uncaring, arrogant, upper class toff in the Commons is unlikely to attract votes. I would recommend the other political parties run a Facebook campaign with picture of RM lounging on the benches in the commons with the caption "vote Conservative, to get a No Deal Brexit, help my offshore investment fund, and lose your job". (Of course I am completely unbiased)

My understanding of what happened Tuesday is that after an MP formally left the Conservative Party, Parliament voted to open the agenda and then put a measure on the agenda for vote on  Wednesday that will require the PM to request an extension of A50 if no WA has been agreed to before 10/31.     Initially, that made me think, "Aha, there'll be an extension of A50!"  Then, it occurred to me that no, there's no extension of A50 until the PM requests it and the EU agrees to it, neither of which has happened, and furthermore, BJ says he will NOT do as instructed, and even if he does, the EU may not vote on it until it meets Oct 17-18. A lot could happen between now and Oct 17th!  And this question is about what will happen FIRST. BJ is saying that if he is forced to ask for an extension of A50, he'll call an election (in hopes of re-gaining a majority and being able to pass legislation that reverses that requirement, and in hopes that having a stronger majority he might be able to negotiate a better deal.) But calling a GE is not something that a PM can do on their own anymore: 2/3rds of Parliament has to vote for an election.  Will it?   I have no idea, but if it does, it could be as early as tomorrow, which would mean that setting a date for a GE would happen first, even if there already was legislation passed which required the PM to request an extension of A50. I think.  This question is so complex with things looping back and crossing lines that I can't figure out how to draw a decision tree for it.  I don't expect to score well, but I sure have learned a lot.  As another forecaster said, "I've been schooled by @Tetbury", but also @nigster, @Emil and others!  Thank you all!  The discussion and sharing on this question epitomizes for me the best of GJO!

Vernon Bognador who is often described as the foremost expert on the constitution is saying that BJ seems to be trying to say that he could turn a vote into Confidence issue and if he loses it call an election. Bognador says this is not allowed under the Fixed Term Parliament Act. BJ would need to get a 2/3 majority to call a GE himself, or Corbyn would have to call a No Confidence motion and win it. He also pointed out that BJ's comment that there was no way he would ask the EU for an A50 extension, was wrong because parliament could tell him to. A guy from Deltapoll gave an explanation of the risk to the Conservative of having a GE. His point was that although the Conservatives appear to be well ahead of Labour in the polls, it was by no mean certain that the Conservatives would get a majority in an election. The reason is that voters have switched parties in a big way since previous elections.  Broadly the Conservatives used to be party of business and the middle class, Labour used to be the party of the Working Class. Gradually the Conservatives became the party of the upwardly mobile, and Labour the party of redistribution. Since 2016 the Conservatives have tried to become the party of Leaving the EU, which has meant trying to get the votes of the very people that were most damaged by the Thatcher Conservative government of the 1980s. but this has driven out many of more liberal Conservatives. The Conservative Party has a majority (when its allies the DUP are included) of one. Several sources are saying that at least twenty Conservative MPs are saying they will vote to ensure a No Deal Brexit does not occur. I have heard nothing, in the last week, that suggests any opposition MPs intend supporting the Government in stopping the anti No Deal MPs. So in theory the anti No Deal MPs have the numbers to stop No Deal.  Threats to deselect  Conservative MPs who  vote against the government have been hinted at, but its not been made official.  (technically remove the Conservative Whip and ban them from standing in an election as Conservative MPs).  How real a threat is this? The Government has a majority of one, so if any Conservative MP has the whip removed, the Government will not have a majority at all. With no majority it would be impossible to govern. Until 2011 a GE would have been called by the PM, but now the PM could only try and get parliament to vote for a GE with a 2/3 majority. A 2/3 majority would need the Labour Party and the Conservative Party to both vote for a GE. Kier Stammer (the Labour Shadow Minister for Brexit made clear today that the Labour Party would not vote with the Conservatives for a GE if it would result in a No Deal Brexit on 30 Oct (so any GE would have to take place after A50 had been extended and the GE would be after 30 Oct.) So I think that rules out a GE called by the PM being "called" (i.e. a date being set) before 30 Oct or before an A50 extension. If Conservative MPs had been deselected what would happen at the next election? Its quite possible that the deselected MPs could stand again for their existing seat but run as an independent. If the election was to take place (say) in November or December the Conservative Party would need to find new candidates. So you could have the "official Conservative" and the "independent conservative" plus all the other parties running against each other. Who knows if either the "official" or "independent" Conservative would win. The "independent" would have name recognition and might win. The "Conservative" vote might be split and someone from another party might win. In any event it would be unlikely to help the Conservative cause. The next election looks very difficult to call, so splitting the Conservative vote would not be a smart move. (An election with "conservatives" having a choice between "No Deal" Conservatives and Brexit Party candidates and "anti No Deal" conservatives.) Starmer is not giving details of the cross party plan to stop a No Deal, but reading between the lines it appears the plan would be (a) try to get the Government to keep parliament open (b) try to get time to try and vote through legislation that would have the effect of extending A50. Items (a) and (b) to take place next week. If this fails then around the 21 Oct have a vote of No Confidence in BJ. If that passed then parliament would vote to see if it had Confidence in Corbyn. If that failed (as it probably would) then immediately have a vote to see if MPs had Confidence in a backbench MPs such as Ken Clark or Harriet Harmon. If it did then they would ask the EU to extend A50. Then MPs would vote on what to do next. That would likely be to both try and get a better Brexit deal from the EU (probably by staying in the Customs Union and Single Market) and then having a public vote. Presumably a GE would happen at some point.  Is what I believe is the anti No Deal plan, likely to be deliverable. I don't see a big problem with the numbers. If 20 Conservatives are committed even if a few chicken out the numbers are there. I doubt that more than two or three Opposition MP would vote with BJ. The problem is the time. I don't know what the government can do toslow things down. Assuming that the Speaker stops attempts to block the bill it should be passed by the Commons. Its less clear how much it could be slowed in the Lords, but the Lords has a means by which Lords can just vote to force another Lord from wasting time with speeches. So I would think there is a 60% chance of getting anti No Deal legislation through. With a vote of No Confidence (now that it appears it is agreed how to follow up and get a new PM) I would give that an 80% chance. So I make that a 92% chance of extending A50.  Previously I was having doubts that anti Brexit MPs had a plan. Today I believe they have.

A lot has changed in the last few days so to help me understand what's due to happen over the next two months I've made a bare-bones parliamentary diary covering the period from now until brexit day;

PARLIAMENTARY DIARY (Parliament sits Monday to Thursday only.) Tue 3 Sept: Parliament returns from holidays. Starmer begins his attempt to block no-deal [1].
Wed 4 Sept
Thu 5 Sept
------
Mon 9 Sept
Tue 10 Sept
Wed 11 Sept: Last day of the current parliamentary session*. Parliament prorogued until 14 Oct.
------
Mon 14 Oct: First day of a new parliamentary session. Queen's speech.
Tue 15 Oct: Debate on Queen's speech 1/5
Wed 16 Oct: Debate on Queen's speech 2/5
Thu 17 Oct: Debate on Queens speech 3/5. EU Council 1/2
Fri 18 Oct: Parliament not scheduled to sit. EU Council 2/2
------
Mon 21 Oct: Debate on Queen's speech 4/5. Votes on Queen's speech 1/2.
Tue 22 Oct: Debate on Queen's speech 5/5. Votes on Queen's speech 2/2.
Wed 23 Oct
Thu 24 Oct
------
Mon 28 Oct
Tue 29 Oct
Wed 30 Oct
Thu 31 Oct: UK due to leave the EU at 11pm. (3 years and 4 months after voting to leave.) * This exact date is speculation. Prorogation is currently scheduled to happen any date from Monday 9th to Thursday 12th September [2] notwithstanding several court cases [3]. There are a number of key decision points in the above schedule where events will go one way or another; KEY DECISION POINTS 1) The Kier Starmer initiative to block no-deal - succeed/fail.
2) The court cases to prevent prorogation - succeed/fail.
3) New/modified withdrawal agreement negotiated at the EU Council - agreed/not agreed.
4) Queen's speech approved by Parliament - approved/not approved. We will know within a few days whether Starmer succeeds in blocking no-deal and whether the courts prevent Boris proroguing parliament. I think when those two variables are known, it will simplify this question quite a lot. [1] https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-49541942

The contributors to the BBC Dateline London program (where mainly foreign media correspondents discuss UK politics) had very similar views to each other pertaining to this question. First none of them thought that the UK was making any serious effort to get a deal with the EU. They assumed he was saying that he was trying to get a deal was just hot air for the benefit of a UK audience. They all rejected the idea that "remainer" MPs trying to stop No Deal would discourage the EU from coming up with a new deal. They pointed out that the UK did not seem serious about the "alternative" arrangements for the Irish border, as it had not set up any trials of the the supposed solutions.  And they thought that no one in the EU wanted to offer BJ anything because they had no trust in him to deliver anything that he agreed. They foreign correspondents were very doubtful that MPs were sufficiently organised to be able to either pass legislation or remove BJ from office to stop No Deal. The one UK national did think parliament had the numbers to block No Deal, but had doubts that would be able do it. All were agreed that the Government (under Cummings the de facto CEO of the UK) was well organised and ruthless. (e.g. any Conservative MP voting against the Government would be deselected and would not able to run as a Conservative at the next election.)  So their conclusion was that No Deal was almost certain.   Steve Richards (the only UK member of the panel) was of the opinion that the Conservative ERG MPs were unlikely to vote for any deal with the EU, and that even if BJ managed to get the EU to agree a Brexit that might be acceptable to enough Labour MPs get get a majority in Parliament, BJ could not put it forward because it would split the Conservative Party permanently. This was in spite of their opinion that BJ really did not want a No Deal but had no way of achieving ant deal. My opinion is that BJ has started a fire that he has lost control of, and can't put it out. The role of Dominic Cummings is critical. His belief in strong, ruthless, single mindedness is both a strength and weakness. The current Government is filled with weak people, but even weak politicians might resent finding just when they achieve what they thought was high office, that their actual role is to dance to the tune of an unelected Special Advisor who sets the policies and runs the government. The staff dismissals that been made shows who is the boss (e.g. Cummings fires Minister's staff without even telling the Minister). I would have thought that spending years to rise to a political office and then be told you can't speak to the media, can't announce policies, and can't chose your own staff, and that your role is simply to vote for what you are told to vote for, would be resented by Ministers. As for MPs their role only exists because the outdated system requires them, it would clearly be easier to shut Parliament permanently.   I think that MPs might be able to "take back control" and stop No Deal. In the longer term I am certain that the current Populist Authoritarian take over will not last.  I note that the Sun and Daily Mail newspapers have headlines claiming that the polls show  that BJ 's closing parliament for 5 weeks  has boosted the popularity of the Conservative Party. The poll they are referring to carried out on 29th/30th Aug has the Conservatives on 31%, which is actually lower than the any of the last 6 polls and almost exactly the same as the polls taken by the same pollster on 6th/11th Aug. 31% is not an obvious number to win an election. The same pollster asked on the same day Should the UK Remain or Leave the EU, 51% said Remain, 46% said Leave. This does not look like much support for the Conservatives or a sign that a GE would be walkover. And to make matter worse he has hired a guy to throw extra petrol on the flames.

I will make no claim to any confidence in my forecast! It has been pointed out that the proroguing Parliament for 5 weeks only reduces the number of planned sitting days between now and 31 Oct by 4 or 5 days, so its not that big a deal. But this ignores the detail. First, BJ knows that MPs were planning to call for a vote on keeping Parliament open during the "conference" period so that this increases the shutdown, but the bigger difference is that what BJ has done is have two separate sessions; 3rd Sep to 12th Sep and then 14th Oct onward. As they will be separate session any business started before 14th Oct but not completed will die, and will have to be started again after 14th Oct. Also normally when a new session of Parliament starts the first week is taken up with the Queens Speech (the statement of what business the session will aim to deliver) and then several days discussion of that business. So in fact there is very little contiguous time to pass legislation. May 4 or 5 days before Prorogation and 5 or 6 days after the new session starts. The Government is suggesting that it has additional ideas of how to block the opposition e.g. by the PM refusing to present new legislation to the Queen so that it does not become law, and/or creating new Bank Holiday Days (Statutory days when businesses, including Parliament are closed), This behaviour is totally new to UK democracy, which has depended on unwritten codes of what is acceptable. It is known that Dominic Cummings does not hold with this. Presumably he learnt a different system of democracy in the years he spent in Russia. Or maybe Munira Mirza (BJ's Director of Policy) learnt it in her years as a Member of the Revolutionary Communist Party. She has studied how Direct Democracy can be used to help Autocratic leaders get power. In any event BJ is not playing by any unwritten rules and so its unclear if he can be stopped.  If Bj would really not get Royal Accent to bills passed by Parliament, or would refuse to step down if he lost a vote of No Confidence I have no idea. Increasing 'new or renegotiated' from 5%. The UK media has gone into complete meltdown this afternoon and is simply not reporting the facts. The government today advised the Queen to prorogue Parliament "no earlier than Monday 9th September and no later than Thursday 12th September 2019 to Monday 14th October 2019" [1]. Parliament voted in July to suspend House of Commons business so that MPs could attend their respective party conferences (which they do every year) [2] so parliament will not be sitting anyway from Thursday 12 September to Wednesday 9 October. So all today's announcement did in terms of parliamentary debating time was move the October opening date from Thursday 10th to Monday 14th. Parliament does not sit on Friday, Saturday or Sunday so only one sitting day has been lost. Boris has prorogued parliament when it was due to be shut anyway, as voted for by MPs in July.
