Revised to take account of yesterdays meeting of opposition parties.  As has been widely reported the opposition parties agreed to work together to try and stop a No Deal Brexit by passing legislation in Parliament requiring the Government to ask the EU to extend A50. The first question is do they have the number of MPs to do this. It is highly probable that they do. It would seem unlikely that more than one or two Opposition MPs would vote against the proposed legislation and very likely that quite a few Conservative MPs would vote for such legislation. For Conservative MPs (most of whom are not in favour of No Deal) voting for an extension to A50 would be far easier to justify than the alternative idea of voting that they had No Confidence in their own PM (although in reality they don't have any confidence in him).  It seems that the opposition to No Deal group is in touch with all the actors that are needed to get this to work (e.g. the speaker, Conservative MPs, the EU, experts on parliamentary procedure).   As the Opposition is backing the legislation route to avoid No Deal I don't see how BJ would be able to get Parliament to agree to let him call a GE. Opposition MPs are fully aware BJ might try and call a GE and are fully aware that BJ can't do that without the Opposition backing a GE call in a vote, and so are fully aware that BJ aim would be achieve a No Deal occurring automatically on 31st Oct. So I can't see a GE being called by the 31st Oct. Of course BJ might try to Prorogue Parliament to prevent the Ext. A50 legislation getting through Parliament. Although (like many things in the UK) it not 100% clear if BJ would be able to Prorogue Parliament in order to stop Parliament voting, it is clear that using Prorogation to block the will of Parliament is not following the spirit of how parliamentary democracy is supposed to work and so might have consequences when the next GE does happen. So I doubt that BJ will risk trying Prorogation. There is a question of would the EU grant an A50 extension? Presumably if the Opposition Legislation just told the PM to request an extension with no reason given, the EU might turn down the request. If the there is no reason given in the legislation for the extension I think it is probable that the EU would grant it (there are talks going on with the EU). But from the UK's point of view there has to be something that happens during the extension period to resolve Brexit. If that is a GE or further talks about a revised deal, all that might achieve is delaying the problem and having exactly the same situation in a few months (or years) time. A resolution to Brexit requires not just leaving the EU, but leaving the EU with a clear framework for the Future Relationship or an agreement to cancel A50.  A No Deal Brexit would not resolve matters. By far the quickest means to a Brexit resolution would be to hold another referendum. If the public voted to Remain after all that would end Brexit. If however the public voted to Leave again unless a majority voted for a specific relationship with the EU nothing would be clear. In my opinion having been stupid enough to have started this process the UK should stay in the EU until the majority of the public vote for or against a specific Future Relationship.  In order to hold a referendum on Brexit A50 would need to be delayed by at least 6 months (until June 2020?).   I don't detect any sign of BJ making any serious attempt to renegotiate changes to May's Deal or putting forward any outline of another deal. I don't see where BJ hopes to finish up in the UK's relationship with the EU. I suspect he has no idea either. He does not appear to be someone who has a plan. His advisors don't appear to be people who have any plans either, apart from having power for powers sake. I guess this is how Popularism works; drift in the current in whatever direction the opinion polls are going.

As below but with reduced probability (40%) that Remain will win the Battle of the Commons.

Th question asks which will happen FIRST.  I have begun by eliminating options 1 and 4.  Option 1 doesn't serve the interests of any of the competing parties.  Option 4 would require a degree of cooperation which is highly unlikely.   Options 6 and 7 - if they occur - are likely to occur before 31 October as a means of resolving the problem.  Therefore their probability of occurring FIRST is increased.  Option 6 seems more likely than Option 7 because (a) the Labour Party is seeking an election to achieve its objective of attaining power and (b) PM Johnson may wish for an election to consolidate his power.  In general very few politicians seem to like to idea of popular votes except as an expedient to get their own preferred policy through.  They would much rather have an election which offers them the prospect of securing enough power to force it through without  a popular vote.  Also, Option 7 requires a "date" to be set for the referendum. Even if one is legislated, it seems unlikely that the date would be set before the calling of an election.  On balance Option 7 is very unlikely and for convenience I have set its probability to 0. We must now address the question of what would happen if an election were called.  If called with PM Johnson in control it would NOT be preceded by an extension of Article 50.  If called by Remainers , they will almost certainly not do so without first extending Article 50 (as failure to do so would lead to their worst possible outcome). In the absence of better information I place equal probabilities on Remainers and Leavers winning the battle in the Commons.   If Remainers win, then Option 5 will occur first.   If PM Johnson wins then I place equal probability on his calling an election first and NOT calling an election first.  If an election is NOT called, then I judge that he will pursue No Deal over a revised deal because (a) the EU have shown reluctance to renegotiate and (b) it would be logistically impossible for them to do so in the time frame. The final probabilities are therefore: Remainers win (Option 5) 50%
PM Johnson in power calls General Election (Option 6) 25%
PM Johnson in power, no General Election, No Deal (Option 3) 25%
No General Election Revised Deal 0% (That's the best I can do for the moment.  The real puzzle is the strategy of the SNP.  Logically one would expect them to favour No Deal as that gives the highest probability for their own desired outcome - i.e. Scottish independence as a revolt against Brexit - but as yet they show no signs of understanding that!!) ps Notwithstanding all the preceding ratiocination, I cannot shake the feeling the BJ will win the Battle of the Commons.  If the probability that Remainers win is reduced to 40%, the other probabilities are then 30% and 30%

New facts; two new polls show Conservatives on 32/33%, Labour 22/21%, Libdems 20/19%. SNP 4%, PC 1%, Green 7%, Brexit P 12/14%. 
(Note 1 SNP is only in Scotland and PC is only in Wales so while their % share of Britain my be small, but is big in there own countries.
 Note 2. Libdems and Greens have electoral pacts in at least some constituencies, and there may be 3 way pacts with PC in Wales, so with FPTP voting the combined percentage of the 3 needs to taken into account, which would be 31/32%),   New spin:
1.Johnson has told reporters in order to do a trade deal with the UK, that the US will have to change its laws to make it easier for the UK to export many classes of goods that are currently either, banned, restricted or subjected to onerous food or safety standards. According to Johnson these goods include; bell peppers, wine, pork pies and shower trays. 
2. An email has been seen that indicates that Johnson has been asking for legal views on proroguing parliament.
3. Many contentious issues are said to be being "considered" e.g. HS2 a very high cost rail link from London to the North that the Brexit Party says it would abandon; reduce fuel duty which has been frozen frozen for several years, its unpopular (what tax is not?) but is supposed to be a "nudge" to help improve air quality and reduce CO2. Expect many more things such as care for the old to be "reviewed" in the next few months.
3. Rumours are circulating that Bj wants an election in mid-October, and wants to call it on 9 Sept.  So what does this all add up to? The "reviews" sound like preparation for GE. They are a great way of dealing with contentious issues as long as the issue is being "reviewed" different groups of voters can be told that the government wants to do exactly what that group wants e.g. young people concerned about the environment can be told that BJ wants cars off the road because they pollute and that he is in favour of public transport, while older drivers in rural areas can be told BJ wants them to have cheaper fuel for their cars, paid for by not building public transport.  I assume the remarks about the difficulty of exporting pork pies etc, to the US are intended to show what a tough negotiator BJ will be. But most people, and particularly the media, will notice what BJ is saying stop UK exports to the US is very similar to what he used to write about, in the 1990s as EU rules that stopped UK exports to the EU. They will also remember that BJ was (is) notorious for making up these types of stories, and so will assume that they are probably either untrue or that BJ has taken a grain of truth and built it into a misleading mountain.  But for now I will assume they are true, which raises the question of what was his purpose of telling reporter about the problems with exporting. The UK has spent 40 years working with all the other countries in the EU to create a Single Market of 28 countries with a population of 500 million people, that originally all had their own product, health, safety, labour, environmental  standards, rules and systems, in order to avoid the export problems that BJ says occur with trade outside the EU. Businesses that trade internationally will tell you that the specific rules in each country are not the problem, its the fact that each trading zone has different rules that creates trade friction. So you can't have one product, produced the same way and packed in the same packaging rolling off the same line, but multiple variations that add to costs and complexity.  So BJs remarks seem to show why a trade deal with the EU which at the moment has the same rules and standards as the UK is worth a lot more to the UK than a trade deal with US that has different standards. Of course BJ may think the US will happily changes its rule to please the UK, but its a lot more likely that UK will be told to change its rules to fit the US (in fact it already has been told that.)  So on the one hand BJ seems to be gearing up for an election, on the other hand his poll numbers don't look that good, and how would he actually engineer such an outcome. As far as I can see the most likely outcome of a GE (before Brexit) with these polling numbers would be a hung parliament, with the Conservatives and Brexit Party both fighting for the same ex-Labour voters in the English Midlands and North. My guess is that the Brexit Pary would get few, if any MPs but would take votes that might have otherwise gone to the Conservatives (there is some doubt that they would because many ex-Labour voters would never vote Conservative). While Labour and the LibDems/Greens seem to be fishing in the same pool the LibDems/Greens tend to be younger, more interested in the environment and not interested in the type of 1960s Socialism that Corbyn is keen on. Corbyn supporters are left wing young people and older tribal Labour supporters. The LibDems tend to be stronger in the South and Labour in the North.  To get Parliament to vote for a GE, BJ would need to persuade Labour and Conservative MPs to take a huge risk of losing their own seats and for their own Parties to end up with fewer seats than they have today. For both groups (the majority of whom do not want a No Deal Brexit) it would increase the risk of No Deal happening (because it could take weeks after a GE to form a new Government). Its possible that MPs would be stupid enough to vote for something they don't want (MPs have not shone in their ability to act rationally over the last 3 years.  So it boils down to how, even if he wants to, would BJ get 2/3 MPs to vote for a GE? Obviously TM got Labour to vote for a GE in 2017 when, like now they were trailing the Conservatives by a long way in the polls. In 2017 voters in the actual election votes differently and more tactically than they had said they would vote in the opinion polls. About half the UKIP supporters seem to have switched, initially they appear to moved to Conservative, but in the last few days they appear to have also switched to Labour. Many voters thought Labour was less of a hard Brexit risk and switched from all the small parties (LibDems, Greens, PC, SNP), Labour might think this pattern would happen again, But the difference was that in 2017 the LibDems, Greens and UKIP were all only polling at 10% or less, which under FPTP means that if your favoured party has less than 20% of support in your constituency it makes sense to switch from voting for who you like, to voting for who you least dislike. In 2019 there are far more constituencies where the LibDems are polling closer to the 20% mark and either the Conservatives or Labour look like the no hopers. So the Conservatives might expect to pick up 5 or 6% extra from the Brexit Party, but it looks unlike that Labour would pick up much from the LIbDems.  If I were advising Labour on a strategy I would refuse to fall for the offer of a GE without first getting an undertaking (legally binding) that BJ would rule out a No Deal Brexit and extend A50 so that a Public Vote on Brexit would happen (and make sure that BJ could not fix the question to be voted on.) As 52% of the public want a Public Votes (vs 29% who don't) doing this would help Labour in a GE as well as avoid a No Deal. Revising following the meeting of Johnson with Merkel and Macron, and the position of Corbyn on stopping No Deal. My reading of what France and Germany seemed to be saying is; its up to the UK to sort out which of its contradictory red lines it really wants, don't expect us to try and solve your problem for you. The position of the EU is unchanged it wants a resolution and it would talk, and could even change the WA but only if the UK first deals with the contradictions. The obvious main contradiction is it needs the befits of the Customs Union and Single Market to give it frictionless trade with the EU and to keep the Irish Border open, but also wants to be outside the Customs Union and Single Market in order to reduce (or control) immigration from the EU and to do FTAs with 3rd countries.  The problem with removing the contradictions is that the ERG section of the Conservative Party will not vote for a WA that includes any commitment to staying in the Single Market and Customs Union. However the ERG only makes up about 10% of MPs. If faced with the option of No Deal or a compromise deal (e.g. an EEA type deal) a combination of the majority of Conservative MPs (say 200) plus a majority of Labour MPs (say another 200) could vote through a WA. Is this very likely, no. Is it possible, yes. Would it mean changing the WA? It could be done by just replacing the Backstop with a statement that the UK would remain in the Single Market and Customs Union at the end of the Implementation Period. The Political Declaration would need to be changed to reflect this. Could it be sold to the ERG? I would sell it on the basis that the WA had got rid of the backstop they did not like, and that if at some future date the UK wanted to leave the Customs Union and Single Market they could give notice and do it (where as the Backstop has no unilateral exit clause, being in the Customs Union and Single Market as part of being in the EEA there is a unilateral exit route.)  Would the EU agree to it? I am going back to what Macron and the EU have said many times before; they are not minded to waste time with talks unless the UK first shifts it position on its red lines. The above would be a shift and I think the EU would be willing to discuss it in detail and if need be extend A50 to give time to produce a revised WA.  I don't see any realistic prospect of the EU agreeing to just remove the Backstop as Johnson has requested, and even if they did its unclear that the ERG would vote for the WA anyway. The "solution" that Johnson is proposing to produce seems to be based on the same ideas already rejected by the EU. The current border with Ireland is a very simple concept. The same rules apply both sides so for most purposes the border is invisible even though the currencies and VAT are different. The "solution" is far more complex and requires forms, registrations and,  because all the rules will over time diverge.   In my opinion there is now more doubt that MPs will block a No Deal. It is no secret that Brexit appeals to the Right and Left Populist/Authoritarian part of politics. Corbyn faction is of the Left Populist/Authoritarian end of the spectrum and he personally wants Brexit (to him the EU is a right wing capitalist conspiracy). As long as the Conservatives get blamed for any problems that arise from Brexit he would be very happy because that gives him a great opportunity to win a GE and being outside the EU he can introduce the hard left socialist policies (nationisations, state aid etc.) that the EU competition rules prevent. So the best outcome for Corbyn would be for him to appear to have tried to save the day by trying to block No Deal, but to have been thwarted by the Conservatives.  Johnson's objectives are in some ways not that different from Corbyn's. His preference would be to get the WA passed, but appears to have no idea how to do it (he's forgotten about a soft Brexit that moderate Conservatives and Labour MPs could both support). So that appears to only leave him the option of a No Deal Brexit. But he knows a No Deal comes with the risk that whoever's fault failure to get a deal is pinned on, is unlikely to win a GE. So either he needs a GE before too much of the disadvantages of No Deal manifest themselves or better he needs to pin the blame for failure to get a Brexit on someone else. As everyone is aware of this so blaming someone else will not be easy.   One way out for Johnson would be to get Corbyn to support the idea of GE. Johnson could just try and get Labour and Conservative MPs to both vote for a GE or to let Corbyn call a Vote of No Confidence with a GE to follow. It might well suit Johnson if Corbyn were to become a caretaker PM, and Extend A50 and then have a GE a few weeks later.  (Blame Corbyn for not delivering Brexit and hope to win a majority in a GE.) But many commentators think that its very difficult to predict how a GE would play out, the polls may be very misleading. In 2017 the Conservatives were on over 45% at the start of the campaign, but ended up with no majority. Labour was on 25% at the start and finished up on 40%. Johnson must be aware of that. The latest poll shows the Conservatives appear to have picked up most of the Brexit Partiy's support (they are on 42%, Labour 28%, LibDems 15%). This is one poll and quite a lot different from other recent polls. The same polling company has consistently been out of steep with other pollsters. It currently shows Remain only 1% ahead of Leave when other polls have Leave between 7% and 4% ahead. But they are also showing that 52% of voters want a Final Deal put to a Public Vote vs 29% who don't. I suspect the 42% support for the Conservatives could be that the people polled expected Johnson's visit to France and German (which happened after the polls were taken) to be likely to result in a deal.    Both Johnson and Corbyn would want to avoid a Public Vote (i.e, a referendum) because they both want Brexit (the Labour Party officially is still unclear, but Corbyn has been against the EU for decades) and the probability is that the public would vote to Remain.  Many MPs will want to avoid a GE (because many of them would lose their seats).  So lots of complexity!

I expect to most forecasters this is stating the obvious; both the UK government and the opposition have no idea what they are doing. So I have rejected the idea that any of the parties has a cunning plan to solve Brexit. This makes forecasting very difficult because its not possible to workout from clues what is going to happen.  The announcement that the Freedom of Movement will end on 31st October is typical. What does it mean? What exactly will be different on 1 November? Why announce it now and then say the details will follow later? Without details the statement means nothing. The only facts that I can extract from the announcement is that the government is afraid of announcing what will be in its post Brexit immigration bill, and afraid of putting in in front of MPs. 
Many of the people I meet have experience of delivering projects (in the UK and abroad and we understand the complexity of getting something new installed and running. We have all dealt with significant projects, but obviously nothing approaching the complexity of Brexit. So naturally we ask each other what the Brexit project looks like compared other projects. Of course Brexit does not look like any project we have ever seen. No sane organisation would plan to introduce such a change in this way. So either the government is bluffing and has no intention of having No Deal, or the government has bluffed its way into a hole of its own making and does not know how to get out of No Deal. 
To give just one example of why No Deal will be a mess, if Freedom of Movement really ends in October. One of my friends is an Italian with a UK Residents Permit, which says its valid until "Indefinite". Does she need the new UK "Settled Status" after Brexit? The Home Office web site says under "Who Should Apply?" that EU citizen need to apply "even if you have a UK Permanent Residents Document". If you follow the process it describes what some types of Permanent Residents Document might be, but none of them are called "UK Residences Permit", but it then says you don't need to apply if your document says "indefinite". So does my friend need to apply for "Settled Status" or not? 
After Brexit will immigration control recognize her very old "UK Residences Permit" allows her into the UK, will the NHS ask to see it if she goes for treatment, will he employer recognize this old document. The Home Office web sites makes it clear that valid documents come in all types, shapes and sizes, they have several valid names and at least some names that are not valid (e.g. if it says "Document Certifying Permanent Residences" that is good, but if it says "Registration Certificate" on it, that is no good.) 
So how is a small business or a landlord supposed to distinguish between EU visitors who are only supposed to be in the UK for a few months, from EU citizen who intend being in the UK for a few years, from EU citizens who intend becoming permanent residents who have some sort of old residences document? As a former employer I had no idea what the difference was between a "certificate of residences" and "Residences Permit". Are employers required to check their employees status every few months? Other countries have ID cards, but not the UK.

If Corbyn wins the vote a process would start to find out if any MP had the Confidence of the House. Corbyn might want it to be him, but he would be very unlikely to chosen.  The reason he is very unlikely to be chosen, is the same reason that MPs would vote to get rid of Johnson,  MPs who are not Labour MPs want to firstly stop a No Deal Brexit, and then have a referendum on Brexit with Remain as an option, and with a Brexit deal option that exists (e.g. the deal agreed my Mrs May or some variation of it). And then have a GE. What they don't want is another PM who talks about deals that don't exist and, is unclear if there would a public vote on any deal. They especially don't want a Labour Government, what they do want is a non-partisan caretaker government that's only policy is delivering a Brexit outcome that does the least economic and political damage.  Many (probably most) Labour MPs also want this.  A "Labour Government" would only have 247 MPs out of a total of 650 MPs so would be unable to govern without the support of other parties. Corbyn is not trusted by many Labour MPs and certainly is not trusted by non-Labour MPs. He has no experience in government. He is a divisive figure. Totally unsuited to being a neutral centrist caretaker. Conservative MPs in particular would not trust the competence of the people in Corbyn's Shadow Cabinet, a Corbyn PM would depend on the votes of Conservative, LibDems and SNP etc. MPs to govern. Its very unlikely that they would give Corbyn their votes.  I am not sure that even Corbyn believes in the idea that he could be a good caretaker PM.  So my view is that the Corbyn letter is not serious about him being PM and is not serious about having a Labour caretaker government. So why write it? My assumption is that people in the Labour Party want Corbyn to look as if he is trying to be PM, when its obvious that he won't get enough MPs to support his bid to be PM, Plan B can be tried.  A Caretaker Government that is formed to deal with one task needs to consist of people from as many parties as possible (to show that its non-partisan in everything except the one task) and it should have as PM a person who has no ambition to remain as PM after the one task is dealt with. A Caretaker PM should not then go on as Leader of a Party into a GE to try and become a majority party leader PM. It also needs to be a person whose political views are as close to the centre as possible   The possible outcomes from Corbyn's move are
 (a) he eventually stands aside, or is pushed aside and an Anti-No Deal Brexit government is formed. This would plan for a referendum, but would first need to extend A50 to give time for it to be held.     
(b) A No Confidence vote is lost by Johnson, but MPs cannot agree on a new PM and Johnson carries on as PM. Not likely because MPs would presumably rather have the Downing Street cat as PM rather than a No Deal Brexit.
(c) To stop losing a vote of No Confidence the PM could promise to extend A50 and hold a GE and/or a referendum. Also not likely, but more likely that option (b).  The other options of course still exist; No Deal Brexit, Mrs May's Deal or a variation is passed by parliament etc. but all are very unlikely as each one produces more problems than it solves. The problem with May's Deal is that it has no real Framework for Future Trade, and no NI border solution. The least damaging exit from the Brexit process is to have the public vote on either a specific detailed Brexit Deal (that includes a future trade framework and solves the NI border problem), or vote to Remain.

The UK Government's willingness to have a No Deal Brexit might be overstated. The Johnson backing newspaper the Daily Telegraph commissioned a set of opinion polls a few days ago and then tried to use the result of one question to show that the public supported a No Deal Brexit. 
The Telegraph claimed that 54% backed No Deal. Many commentators have argued that the wording of the question was loaded and pointed out that the Telegraph had also adjusted the actual percentage by excluding the 20% who "did not know".
The pre-adjusted figure was 44% that agreed "that Boris needs to deliver Brexit by any means possible including suspending if necessary in order to stop MPs from stopping it". The question did not mention No Deal at all. ). 
The more interesting results of this set of polls were for other questions.
Brexit should be halted if problems over the NI border threaten to split the Union? 39% agreed, 37% disagreed
Are you Concerned or Not Concerned about supplies of Fresh Food after No Deal? 53% Concerned, 40% not concerned.
Concerned or No Concerned about supplies of medicine after No Deal? Concerned 59% not concerned 32%.
Are you concerned about the cost of living increasing in the event of No Deal? Concerned 68% , not concerned 24% How loaded the questions are is the not my point here. What Johnson should be have noticed is that most of people polled believed that No Deal creates a lot of concerns. The majority of people don't want No Deal (other polls have shown that) and if he delivered No Deal and any of the concerns turned into real problems he would be in political trouble. Its a lot easier to be macho if you don't think about the consequences, but if the PM does something that does not work out well the PM gets the blame. 
So I think Johnson will not allow No Deal regardless of parliament stopping him.
My personal view backed by no hard evidence, but looking at Johnson's body language is that he is looking very worried. His tactics of setting red lines before starting talks with the EU seems to have backfired, as did Mrs May's. Setting very public red lines makes it very difficult to get agreement because backing down is then also very public for both parties. Making threats to shoot yourself in the head is also not usually a good tactic, as it carries the high risk that your opponent will just let you go ahead. His only exit from the corner he has put himself in may to allow MPs to block No Deal, but to do so in way they they would be blamed by the significant minority of voters who don't mind No Deal.

NB: I don't think the options are mutually exclusive. There will probably be a date for a GE, despite the UK leaving. But generally, I expect that in absence of any realistic options, the UK will leave without a deal.

The PM continues to make announcements for spending on "popular"  policies which appear to be aimed at appealing to Brexit Party supporters and the new populist wing of the Conservative party  which would suggest he is thinking about a GE. However while the Conservatives lead the polls on voting intention if there was a GE, they are a long way short of the figures that would guarantee a Conservative win. (e.g. Conservatives on 31% now, at the 2017 GE they got 42% and did not get a majority, at the 2015 GE they got 37% and a majority). A more similar (to now) spread of votes was the 2010 GE when the  Conservatives got 36%, Labour got 29%, LibDems got 23%. At this election UKIP's support in the opinion polls almost disappeared at the actual GE. If the same were to happen to the Brexit Party in 2019 it is not clear if the Conservatives would pick up their votes or not. The Conservative Party has clearly changed since 2010 and its policies are very similar to the old UKIP (the Brexit Party does not have policies as such) so the Conservatives might pick up extra votes from the Brexit Party, but if the Brexit Party vote does not collapse it would split the vote of Brexit supporters. The 2010 GE still  resulted in a hung parliament  My conclusion is that a GE would be a very high risk for both Conservatives and  Labour, but Johnson has built up expectations. Most UK voters now expect Brexit to happen on 31st Oct and most of them expect it to be a No Deal Brexit (most voters don't want No Deal, but they expect it.) . If Johnson fails to deliver his credibility is shot. Most voters don't want the negotiated deal so if that happens voters will be unhappy. Most voters don't want No Deal (but expect it) so if that happens voters will be unhappy. No Deal has the potential to be noticeably bad. So the PM appears to have a big problem. A GE while ahead in the polls is an attractive idea  for the PM when delay is likely to be produce a worse result. But for individual MPs its not such an attractive idea when many of them are likely to lose their seats.  It looks as if a lot of sitting MPs could lose their seats in a GE because those supporting each party are in flux. The New Labour supporters are deserting the Labour Party. The liberal wing of the Conservative Party are deserting the Conservatives, so both are likely to lose seats where they have traditionally had strong support, even if they pick up some new ones in other places. The national opinion poll percentages for party support are misleading because voters are aligning in different ways to how they have previously.   It seems unlikely that a No Deal Brexit would happen before a GE is announced, because it seems inconceivable that the majority of voters would feel their lives had improved after a No Deal Brexit. Even the Brexiteers concede their will be "bumps in the road for while" after Brexit. So a GE after a No Deal (after the first day or so) would be hard for the Conservatives to win, as they would have to explain what the befits of the "bumps in the road" were, and they would have to explain to voters who had assumed that Brexit was the end of the process, that it was just the start of the new process of trying to do new trade deals, and trying to build new alliances,l and settling into a a new place in the world. None of this adjustment would be easy.   Its unlikely that the rush to invest in the new post Brexit reality will happen until the major new trade arrangements are implemented. How long that would take is anyone's guess. There could be a quick trade deal with the EU, but that would almost certainly only happen if it looked like being in the Single Market and Customs Union, if not its likely to take years to sort out (in the meantime business investment will have gone elsewhere.)

A no-deal Brexit is odds-on. If I were betting, I'd rate it as 2/1 on or shorter, hence the 70% forecast. #1 The UK will leave the EU with the November 2018 Withdrawal Agreement in place
It is not the current government policy and the route by which this could happen if the agreement is put up for vote by the government, which doesn’t look likely. No other route looks feasible (e.g. a caretaker government) #2 The UK will leave the EU with a new or renegotiated version of a Withdrawal Agreement in place
Renegotiation must include agreement from both the UK and EU. The UK government has asked for big pre-conditions for negotiations to re-start (dropping the backstop) and the EU government doesn’t seem to be prepared to do so. However the chance of renegotiation is not trivial because enough time still remains for either party to change their mind. #3 The UK will leave the EU without a Withdrawal Agreement in place
This is currently the default option and the negotiation position of both parties seems to imply that this is the most likely outcome. However the sequence is important here, there is a non-trivial chance that while ‘no deal’ could be the eventual outcome, a date for General Election is set before this occurs. It is currently being discussed that a plausible scenario is that the Government loses the confidence vote (which means setting an election date) but pushes through a ‘no deal outcome before election is held. #4 The UK will revoke Article 50
This is unlikely as was not a popular choice during the MP voting cycles so it doesn’t look like there is majority in the parliament for this option without a new referendum. One remote scenario is that a caretaker government steps in to revoke, however that doesn’t look plausible.  #5 The UK's Article 50 period will be extended beyond 31 October 2019
An extensio is a likely scenario since this was the previous route taken by the last PM. However there are three things that make it less likely. 1) Firm stance by the UK government to leave on 31 October. 2) Requirement of the EU to agree an extension and the fact that they might not agree if there is no line in sight for any changes to the position (Macron’s argument), 3) Sequence of events might mean that the date for a General Election is set first and only then extension is given. I give it a fairly high probability as despite the points above, there could be a ‘technical’ extension of a few days / weeks to allow finalising negotiations for example. #6 The UK will set a date for a General Election
Early general election looks increasingly likely due to ever-diminishing majority of the UK government and the staffing decisions made (i.e. more focus on campaign than governing). There have also been a number of rumours / comments by people close to the government saying that election is likely to be called soon. That basic principle aside, the timing of setting an election date is crucial for that question and it is not obvious. For this option to be right, government either has to do it independently or through loss of a confidence vote (which looks to be planned for September). There seems to be a reasonable chance that an election might be on the cards, but the date is not set before other options occur. #7 The UK will set a date for a referendum on Brexit
New referendum is not a policy of either of the large parties so it is a low probability option. There are two ‘wild card’ scenarios that I see, either a caretaker government comes in and decides to hold a new referendum (instead of an election, - looks very unlikely) or due to PM’s desperation to stay in power, he calls a new referendum and therefore stays in power until that date (also looks very unlikely)

There is no sign that anyone in the UK has any real plan of what to do. Cummings (Johnson's advisor) is spreading a lot of misinformation. Presumably he is trying to provoke MPs into having a vote of No Confidence in Johnson in order to blame them for Johnson not delivering Brexit by the end of October. If a No Confidence vote is lost by the PM either Parliament will be able to find another PM who will Extend A50 (so that will be the first thing to happen) or it will lead to a GE, before or after the end of Oct. If the UK is heading for a GE either A50 is Extended first or the Date of the GE is set first. Leaving the EU without a Deal (No Deal) would only occur first if Parliament failed to win a No Confidence vote (i.e. did not hold a vote or Johnson won the vote) and Johnson allowed the UK to Leave the EU without any other action.
I think Johnson is bluffing and would not want to Leave the EU on No Deal terms because while the Conservatives might reduce the attraction to (some) voters of the Brexit Party (and hope to pick up votes) a GE would probably be needed anyway (due to lack of Conservative MPs). A GE after a NO Deal Brexit is unlikely to go well for the Conservatives because while many voters say they support No Deal no one really knows how much much disruption No Deal would cause, but is seems fairly certain that some voters will find they are seriously negatively affected and its very unlikely that any voters will find that their lives have improved. In these circumstances it would be easy and logical of many voters to blame the Party and person that caused the problem and not vote for them. Obviously I could be totally wrong but Cummings is often described as very clever. As far as I can see his cleverness has not been in the field of negotiating deals, but in the field of using behavioral economics to influence voting, in much the same way that advertisers do. e.g. taking advantage of voters preferences to use automatic fast thinking rather than reflective slow thinking and using targeted ads to very small subsets of voters and carefully measuring which adverts get each sub-groups attention. In other words he is expert in doing the opposite of what Thaler and Sunstein's "Nudge" aims to do, which is "Improve decisions about health, wealth and happiness". What Cummings is aiming to do is take advantage of the human frailty whereby we prefer to take the lazy fast, but wrong choices (as per Homer Simpson) , to the taking of more difficult logical choices (as per Mr Spock). I don't see how his methods would be of any advantage in negotiating  with the EU. (But maybe he has other skills that I am not aware of.)

(no meetings with EU heads of states or with EU negociator Barnier) Johnson cabinet choices and selection of Dominic Cummings, seems to indicate Johnson is preparing for early elections, probably forced by parliament.   It is unlikely that the EU will change tack. Given the British internal opposition to no-deal, they have little to gain in making concessions now. Opening doors to Johnson reduces possibility of no-deal, and reduces the ability of parliament to oppose Johnson. If Parliament was to get in line with Johnson and the UK presented a united front,  the EU could consider concessions. This means a new withdrawal agreement is unlikely. Both sides of the power struggle in Westminster - leave and remain - must by now have formulated their plans for the next three months. The government's public strategy is to prepare for no-deal in order to get a deal, however there's no indication of what they want from the EU. So in the same way that Theresa May's lack of no-deal planning betrayed the fact that she never expected to leave without a deal, this government's lack of deal planning betrays the fact that it has no expectation of a deal. Remainer MPs strategy seems to be to get control of the parliamentary timetable then if that fails, trigger a confidence motion and form a unity government. I keep expecting to hear rumours of clever secret plots from one side or the other but so far none is forthcoming so maybe it's as simple as it looks; the Boris government is expecting to leave without a deal by running down the clock and remainer MPs are hoping to block him using parliamentary procedure or a no confidence motion. If that is what's going on then even one week before brexit day these four buckets could still be in play; • leave with a deal
• set date for a GE
• extend A50
• no-deal

There is no consensus in Parliament for a no deal, so MPs will find a path to stop this. Both major parities would prefer to avoid a General Election and would not have the clarity nor agreement on a new referendum question, so the most likely event is to request an extension on the basis that MPs plan to find a path possibly with a new cabinet of cross party, leave and remain MPs building on the spring’s indicative voting, where MPs are free to vote regardless of party lines or even the appointment of a People’s Assembly if the arithmetics continue to be an impass in Parliament.

The results of the Brecon election are in. 
The most significant thing they show is that the claims of the politicians are much exaggerated.  Changing the PM has made little difference to how people voted. 
There is no evidence that voters are desperate for a No Deal Brexit or that they are desperate for a People's Vote.
The Conservatives did 10% better in the actual vote than they did in the pre-election polls, and The Brexit Party did 10% worse. PM Johnson might claim that it is down to him, but realistically it would be expected that as with  UKIP  or any small party, that many people who tell pollsters they will vote for it, tactically switch their vote to a party with more chance of winning the actual election. 
The LibDem vote held steady in the actual votes to the percent it had in the pre-election polls. 
Although UKIP has never got many votes in Brecon it has become irrelevant.
The position of Labour in Brecon is that under the first past the post system it was never likely to win and so its not a great surprise that some of it supporters voted LibDem and some for The Brexit Party. But it does show that a Corbyn Labour Party has little chance of winning a GE.
Its unlikely but possible that if Labour does not change its leader it will fade away, with its liberal (New Labour) wing switching to the LibDems and its conservative working class support going to the Conservatives, leaving just the radical hard left. Mirroring this the Conservative liberal wing support could continue its move to the LibDems. Locally this is not crazy because Labour grew as the party of the industrial worker, and as industrial workers are disappearing the point of the party is disappearing. 
Tactically the LibDem, Green and PC pact worked well, and it should work in other places.  In Parliament having the Conservative + DUP majority down to 1 makes a No Deal a little less likely. 
Having no evidence of voters willing to "do or die" to Leave the EU by the end of October does not boost PM Johnson's case to the EU.   He certainly can't claim a mandate from voters for No Deal. 
It shows that First Past the Post disenfranchises most voters (Parliament will only have an MP who has at most 43% support of the voters of Brecon, the other 57% will be represented by a party they don't agree with.)

As others (e.g. @nigster) have noted today could be significant to this question as there is a election in Wales (Brecon). In  the 2016 referendum it voted very close to the UK average (51.86% Leave, 48.14% Remain).
The seat was held by the Conservatives with 48.1% in 2017, LibDems got 29.1%, Lab 17.7%, PC 3.1% and UKIP 1.4% This election will be significant for two reasons; which Party wins, and do the combined votes of parties that back Remain or Leave get the most votes.  If the Conservatives lose their Parliamentary majority (even including the DUP who are supporting them) drops to 1. If the Conservatives, Brexit Party and UKIP between them get over 50% of the total vote they can claim some sort of mandate for a No Deal Brexit, if they get under 50% then it can be claimed that there is no mandate for a No Deal Brexit. Obviously as No Deal Brexit is not on the ballot everyone will claim the result supports their view.  I expect to revise my forecast of this question according to the result of this election. If the Conservatives lose then getting No Deal past Parliament will be more difficult. If the  three pro-Brexit parties get over 50% PM Johnson will press on with the threat of No Deal, which will become a more likely outcome.  If the three parties get below 50% other Conservative MPs may worry about losing their seats if No Deal were to happen.   If Labour does very badly it could lead to calls to get rid of Corbyn. 
If the Brexit Party does better than the Conservatives that will lead to panic in the Conservative Party.
If UKIP does very badly it might just give up.
If the Loony Party wins, its time to emigrate.

@dowser (is this comment you asked me to repost as a forecast?)  @Chrisp
The majority of EU citizens when they move to another EU country don't change their nationality. They can vote in EU elections and local elections. but not national elections. The numbers vary from year to year, but in 2017 only 3 EU countries were in the top 10 countries of migrant origins of people granted UK citizenship and the total number of EU nationals granted citizenship was only around 14,000. Hardly enough to swing any future votes.
Those EU citizen that become UK citizens were mainly because they had married a UK citizen or they were EU citizens who were born in the UK.
Most internal EU migrants do not intend remaining in the country where they are currently living for the rest of their lives. Most intend either returning to their native country or moving to whatever country offers them the best opportunities. I know many people who have done that, or are doing that. Its much like internal migration within the UK or within the USA. You see an opportunity, you move to where it is. It may be for a short term project or you may be there for years. The actual Brexit vote was:
"England voted for Brexit, by 53.4% to 46.6%. Wales also voted for Brexit, with Leave getting 52.5% of the vote and Remain 47.5%. Scotland and Northern Ireland both backed staying in the EU. Scotland backed Remain by 62% to 38%, while 55.8% in Northern Ireland voted Remain and 44.2% Leave."
I don't know where you got your figures from for England? I have discussed the Brexit issues with lots of Leavers and Remainders, and I have asked contacts to ask other Leavers to ask specific questions on their attitudes, so I have quite a good idea what Leavers think. The issue of social changes comes up talking to Leavers and Remainers. The difference is that Remainers tend to not equate the changes with immigration, but with other factors and accept that things do change. The Leavers tend to be more upset by changes and are keen to blame someone or something for the changes. In some places the changes appear to be linked or at least coincide with the migration of EU citizens from Eastern Europe. So some examples; there have been changes to church attendances. The number of native British people attending church as been falling for many years. The Catholic Church (in particular) has had problems. In the Church of England the Church is far more liberal than many of the congregation, is, its attitude to gay people has changed, it has women and black ministers. I have been told by Catholics they don't like the fact that the church is now "full of immigrants". If the immigrants had not been there its probable that the church would have closed due to lack of a congregation. So we have a social change that few go to church (not due to immigrants) but rather than welcome the fact that the church only continues because of the immigrants they somehow blame the immigrants for the change. Of course as few Brexit voters actually go to church the immigrants don't really affect them, but (some) Brexit voters have said the social change to churches was a reason for wanting Brexit (even if does not affect them at). Many long establish chains of shops have closed. Leave voters tend to tell me that the closure of a high street shop makes them sad. This sadness has little to do with any inconvenience they may suffer from the shop being closed, because I have establish that they feel almost as sad when a shop they had never actually been a customers of closes, as they do when a shop they actually use closes. If the long established shop gets replaced by a new shop with a foreign name or it sells foreign stuff the Leavers equate the old shop closing to the increase of immigrants. The reality is that the old shops are closing because retailing is moving online. Its a similar picture with banks. Almost all the banks in small town have been closed in the last ten years. Not because of immigrants but because their customers use the branches less because most people bank online. The Leavers tend to get angry or sad about it. The Remainers tend to be a bit irritated that on the rare occasions when they might want to visit a bank they can't, but they realise that the closure was because people like them had stopped using the branch, so they shrug and carry on using internet banking. Pubs have closed in large numbers. There are few of the old fashioned traditional pubs left. What has replaced them are family restaurants and coffee shops. For those who used to spend their leisure time smoking and drinking in their local pub things have changed a lot. With smoking banned inside they have sit outside. The reason for the changes are customers don't want to go to the old pubs, society has changed but not due to immigrants. Old businesses have closed, repairs shops hardly exist, heavy industry declined decades ago, now light industry is in decline the Leavers find this upsetting, Remainers see this as inevitable change. Its got nothing to do with immigration, but Leavers tend to equate change with immigration So my point is two things have happened at roughly the same time, changes and EU immigration. In many cases they are not related at all, but Leavers tend to treat the coincidence as if it was the cause. Is there any other evidence? I think there is. This idea of linking things that happen at about the same as being due to the same cause, when its not is not new. In 1516 the Spanish Royal line ended and was replaced by the Habsburg Charles V who came from what is now Belgium. May civil servants went from Flanders with him to Spain. At about the same time migrants who were originally from India arrived in Spain having crossed from North Africa. They brought with them a style of singing, dancing and music. The Spanish public assumed that the arrival of this new music had been brought by Charles V, so they called it Flamenco (or Flemish). In the US when Trump was elected his supporters seem to have had a similar issue with the changes to their lives as the Brexit voters did in the UK. But in the US there was no big increase in immigration to the areas where people voted for Trump. So we have two groups of people, one in the UK, one in the US, who felt that their lives were changing for the worse. The group in the UK blamed the changes on Eastern European immigration, the US group blamed it on other things that they could not control. My point is that if the reason to Leave the EU was immigration, stopping immigration from the EU is not going to help the Leavers with the real problems they have. Leaving the EU is not going to bring Woolworths back or bring back smoke filled pubs, or fill the churches with native Englanders. So Brexit will fail because its identified real problems but the wrong cure.

Again building off the analysis of other forecasters here, options assessed in order listed... Leave w/ May's Deal: 1% (4↓)
 - Seems to be effectively a non-starter on both sides of the isle. Certainly not impossible, but very unlikely. Leave w/ Renegotiated: 0% (5↓)
 - This is very unlikely given the timeline, however given BoJo's hardline towards a no-deal Brexit I see this as effectively impossible (to happen first). Leave w/o a deal: 25% (20↑)
 - I see this as being one of the more likely outcomes given BoJo's persistence on a no-deal route. It's certainly not a given yet but with time running down there are limited options remaining. Wildcard here is the possibility of a vote of no-confidence in order to avoid such a route. Revocation of A50: 1% (4↓)
 - Again technically not impossible, but this appears not to be a practicable option. Extension of A50: 35% (19↑)
 - Swapping likely order w/ the option of setting a date for a referendum. Setting of a Date for a GE: 33% (7↓)
 - This is a tricky one & I'm not entirely sure how the progression would look here, but I see the primary path towards this option now as being similar to the order of setting a date for a referendum. AKA it is unlikely that this would occur before an extension of A50, unless...
 - Unless a vote of no-confidence against BoJo passes... In this event I would see the progression as [Vote of NC → Date for GE set → Extension to A50 → Date for Referendum set]. If a NC vote is raised & passed this becomes my all in option, and I will look to increase the likelihood on this significantly. Setting of a Date for a Referendum: 5% (20↓)
 - From what I can decipher it is impossible to hold such a referendum w/o an extension to A50 as such a referendum would take 22 weeks to hold. Thus the only question here is could a date be set on the premise that an extension was imminent but not yet officially granted? I view this as highly unlikely but not impossible tl;dr...
 - Only real progression I see are (in order of likelihood) 1a) BoJo pushes for a no-deal Brexit & triggers a vote of no-confidence. Vote passes & an extension is requested & granted in the immediate aftermath, followed by a date for a GE & referendum
1b) BoJo pushes for a no-deal Brexit & triggers a vote of no-confidence. Vote fails & a no deal Brexit occurs.
2) BoJo backs down on no-deal exit talks & requests an extension
3) BoJo pushes for a no-deal Brexit but a vote of no-confidence fails to be brought, anarchy ensues (Partially joking on the anarchy part).

I find this question extremely confusing and very challenging.  I'm very appreciative to @Tetbury, @cafebedouin, @nigster and others who have set me straight on a number of facets of it. So, here's my current thinking:  from least likely to occur first (#7) to most likely to occur first #7 REVOKE. 0% (no change)  @Chrisp says that there are sufficient Remainers in Parliament that they could Revoke without election.  Maybe, in theory, but the fact that this hasn't happened suggests to me that it won't, because so many of the MPs who are Remainers represent folks who are Leavers.  I think it's more likely there'll be a No Deal Brexit or a referendum, or one of the other options, than that A50 will be revoked. #6 LEAVE W/ May's WA:  0% (no change)  As @Tetbury says, "May's deal is actually the nearest to what voters were told Brexit would be by many of the leaders of the Leave campaigns" but Parliament isn't going to go for it after having voted it down 3x.  There will have to be an extension first to hold a referendum on it or there will first have to be a GE to get a new parliament to vote for it.   #5 LEAVE W/ new WA: very difficult, but not impossible. 3% (no change)  Other forecasters have pointed out that it seems that the EU thinks No Deal would be the worst outcome, so even though the EU has repeatedly said that they won't negotiate further, they probably will.  As @Chrisp points out:  "On a No-deal Brexit, the backstop is gone. So the question for the EU is this: is an orderly withdrawal without the backstop better than a disorderly withdrawal."    Or perhaps the new PM can wrangle some minor superficial changes so that he can call it "new and improved" WA.  It can't happen before 10/31, and is likely to require an extension, so it would not be the option from this list that happens first.    #4 LEAVE W/NO DEAL.  Is an increasing possibility given what the PM continues to say.  16% (no change) I am totally confused about who--the PM? Parliament?--can stop a No Deal Brexit.  If I understand @Tetbury correctly, Parliament may be able to block a No Deal Brexit and @cafebedouin says  Parliament can stop a No Deal Brexit by changing the law, but @Tetbury later said:  "Assuming [AG] Cox is right and parliament cannot stop No Deal Brexit, a PM pushing it through just because he could not be stopped would not look too good on the PMs CV unless the No Deal was such a great and instant success that the pubic forgot it. My guess a PM who did this would become an even bigger hate figure for all those affected than Margaret Thatcher became. They say that Johnson is (rather like Trump) a man with no friends who longs to be loved by people. Would he want his legacy to be the most hated PM in living memory?" Clearly, however, there's no way that the EU can stop a No Deal Brexit. #3 SET a DATE for a REFERENDUM.   16% (decreased from 33%)  Some scenarios in which there may be a 2nd referendum are: -progress has been made in negotiations and there's a new WA, but Parliament won't go for this new WA. Since there seems to be public support for the "right kind" of Brexit and the PM may be most reluctant to call a GE to try to get the votes in Parliament, rather than call a GE, the PM might call for a referendum. -all other avenues have been blocked: Parliament has voted to deny the PM the right to leave with no deal, or the EU won't give the UK an extension so it can complete negotiations on a new WA; (however, in this situation the request for an extension would have come first).  -to deflect blame/responsibility from the PM and Parliament.   -with No Deal looming, the public clamors for a vote . . .  -It  make some sense to have a national vote again even though May's WA has been voted down by Parliament 3x.
However, the idea of a 2nd referendum is outrageous  in the minds of Leavers.  @nigster says, ". . . .to brexiteers a second referendum is a betrayal of democracy. If there was a 2nd ref. it would make me question everything about this country that I was brought up to believe. If politicians are our rulers not our representative, if they can override a clear democratic vote, then what next? The government loses an election but says "those stupid working class people didn't know what they were voting for so they must vote again". Or "the opposition lied so lets vote again". Or "most of the people who voted against the government didn't go to university so we must vote again". Where does that end? . . .  The most depressing and also the scariest thing to me about brexit is that smart and decent friends of mine who voted remain do not see that making people vote again is wrong. . . .  All of the leave voters would be utterly outraged by a 2nd ref.  . . "   @cafebedouin has convinced me that if the PM or Parliament wanted to hold a referendum, it would get the EU to agree to an extension while it worked out the language, set the date, etc for the referendum, so setting a date for a referendum would not happen until an extension had been requested & granted. #2 SET A DATE for a GE:  30% (increased from 26%) The PM may not want to do this as polls & recent election results seem to suggest that his party would lose many seats.  (See @Tetbury for a more comprehensive analysis of this.)   If the polls changed, all bets are off!  Also, if threatened by a No Deal Brexit or forced to form a new government by a no confidence vote, this may be seen as the least bad option. @nigster says:  "One possibility that exists (but I have hardly seen mentioned in the media) is that a GE is triggered by the opposition but Boris simply sets a date for the election such that we leave on 31 October then the election happens shortly afterwards."   This scenario, then, has setting a date first, followed by Brexit, then an election. @nigster also said:  "The Fixed Term Parliaments Act sets a minimum time from triggering a GE to polling day but it leaves setting the date of the GE to the discretion of the Prime Minister. A Times article today said that Attorney General Geoffrey Cox is understood to believe that there is no legal basis to prevent the prime minister from taking Britain out of the EU, even if October 31 arrives amid a general election campaign triggered by a no-confidence vote in the government over no-deal." @Chrisp also says: "The PM (and the queen) lost that ability [to call a GE]   with the fixed parliaments act." Will there be a vote of Confidence, when, and how will BJ fare?   @Tetbury says:  "Only the Leader of the Opposition can call for a Vote of No Confidence in the Government.
Conservative MPs can choose to remove Johnson from being their Leader, but that does not stop him being the PM." @Chrisp says, "Right now the conservatives have enough votes to block a no confidence vote - however several conservatives have said they will vote to bring down the government in the event of a no deal Brexit. . . . There is nothing to prevent a no-confidence vote - except that right now a lot of tories, and quite a few labor know that it will end their political careers." @Tetbury sums it up thusly (edited):  ". . . the PM can no longer just call an election.  He has to get MPs to vote for it with a 2/3 majority, and [then] the PM would be able to set the date of a GE. Or the Labour opposition has to first win a Vote of No Confidence and then if no alternative candidate for PM can win a Confidence Vote the PM has to call a GE. It seems that many forecasters see this as the option most likely to be in play in the short term even though the PM and many MPs will/could lose their positions if one occurs.  @cafebedouin suggests that the PM" might use an election tactically as a surprise move to prevent Parliament from taking any action against a no deal Brexit," or "to change the composition of Parliament to pass May's deal." #1 EXTEND.  35% (increased from 22%) The EU and a majority in the UK & Parliament do not want a no-deal Brexit. An extension could be necessary (and palatable to the PM) if there appeared to be some possibility of negotiations becoming fruitful. It would also be needed if there was to be a referendum (since they take 22 weeks to hold).  If there is going to be a GE, the UK & EU might opt for an extension rather than have a No Deal Brexit.   THIS MUST HAPPEN BEFORE 10/31 IF IT IS TO HAPPEN AT ALL. The likelihood of it is linked to the progress of negotiations with the EU; if progress is being made, I don't think the UK will ask for it until the last minute.   @cafebedouin has convinced me that even a last-minute request by the UK for an extension will get through the EU, as "there's no way the EU is going to set themselves up as the bad guy if an extension is asked for and not granted". As @Chrisp suggests, " . . . one way Extend happens is the PM loses a noconf and Remainer Tories and Labor form a government." @cafebedouin has said for an extension to happen, 1) Parliament must pass legislation that changes the October 31 date or  2) after a no confidence vote some kind of caretaker government is formed with the sole purpose of changing the deadline. But @Chrisp counters:  "I don't agree think it is settled that Parliament can change the extend date. Remember, Theresa May changed the date without Parliament, and that's because an official government or head of state is what's required. Parliament - regardless of what laws it passes - is neither of those." All of this adds up to muddy waters for me! From my perspective it seems that every side in this situation has done its best to erect a wall to prevent others from achieving their goals.  Linked together, all of these walls have left no maneuvering room, no space for compromise, no common ground.  Everyone's hands are tied by their own words/actions or those of their opposition.  So, which walls will be the most fiercely defended?  which will be breached?  Who will release themselves from the bonds/commitments that they have made? FINAL COMMENT:

In the last few days the media has picked up signs of the testing of political adverts being placed on social media websites by the Conservatives and other signs that they interpret as looking like the start of of an election campaign. The question they are asking is when will the GE be.  Johnson has said there will definitely be no GE before 31st Oct, but (the media say) this could be part of the mind games that the PM's election team is playing, and of course we know that May said there would be no GE in 2017 and then went for a walk one day and changed her mind. So I am ignoring what the PM says. If it looked as if Johnson could win an election I am sure he would not bother with what he said yesterday. What is more likely stopping Johnson calling a GE is that currently it looks as if the Conservatives would loose seats, not gain them. The polls (for a GE)  show the Conservatives on only 25% (at the last GE they got 42%) there has been no Boris bounce so far.  If the polls are not to be believed there is also the evidence from an actual election to consider. On Thursday (day 2 for the new PM) a  two small local elections took place in Gloucestershire (for the local Council). In each constituency there were Conservative, Labour, LibDems, Greens, UKIP and Brexit Party candidates (the first time the Brexit Party had stood for a domestic election). Of interest was how would the new Brexit Party do and how would it affect the Conservative and Labour vote.  One of these seats had been held by the Conservatives. This seat was won by the LibDems, with the Conservatives well behind in second place and the Brexit P. a long way behind that. Even if the Conservative, Brexit P, and (tiny) UKIP votes were added together the LibDems would have still won. Presumably this had been a Conservative area that did not like way Brexit was going. The other seat had been held by Labour, it was also won by the LibDems, just ahead of the Conservatives, with Labour third just ahead of the Brexit Party. My guess is that this area had been Labour Pro-Brexit and that Labour lost votes to the LibDems (from anti-Brexit Labour voters).  Its clearly complicated as voters are shifting from the Right/Left division to Inclusive/exclusive (or liberal/illiberal, or Leave/Remain however you want to define it) but what is clear is that figuring out what the result of a GE when the Cons are polling 25%, the LibDems are on 23%, Labour is on19%, the Brexits are on 17% and the Greens are on 9%, is very difficult. The LibDems are working with other parties (Greens and PC) in local pacts, which adds to the complication. What does seems clear is that calling a GE when you are only polling 25% would be unlikely to give you a majority in Parliament. But the possibilities of tactical voting and local pacts are endless, and too many to explore here.  (If there was a Conservative/Brexit Party pact (or a LibDem/Green pact) would voters actually vote for a party they did not support just because it was in a pact?) However my main reasons for thinking a GE before November is very unlikely is that it would need to be called by mid-September, Before mid-September it seems unlikely that the PM could claim that a GE is needed because the EU is refusing to negotiate with the UK, or because "remoaners" are blocking a No Deal Brexit. According to the truth (according to the Brexit Believers) the EU always gives you want you want at the last minute. The "last minute" will not have arrived before mid-September. For similar reasons the "last minute" to stop No Deal will not have arrived by mid-September, so that can't be the reason for calling a GE.  I presume that Dominic Cummings will try and provoke anti-Brexiteers into taking some action that can then be blamed for stopping Johnson from achieving his target of Brexit by the end of October. I also presume that the anti-Brexiteers and the anti-No Dealers (two different groups) are well aware of this and will try and avoid giving Johnson the excuse that he had to Extend A50 because his No Deal Brexit was blocked. I note that the latest Sky Poll on people's preferred Brexit outcome (24th July) shows 41% prefer to Remain in the EU, 15% would prefer a deal similar to the May Deal, and 26% would prefer to Leave the EU with No Deal, (17% had no opinion). Since January this poll has shifted with 3% more preferring to Remain,  5% fewer wanting a Brexit Deal like May's and 3% fewer wanting No Deal.  It would be brave PM who would risk a No Deal Brexit when 76% of voters don't support it. (I know there are other polls that have other conclusions).    So things could change but today I think a GE very unlikely, but not impossible.
Shifting a bit more toward the two WA buckets. There may be more momentum to just get past this issue, but the amount of effort to minimize pain still seems daunting.

In the dawn of a “golden age” under Bojo, I’m counting on his signature flip flops to keep things interesting.
https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-politics-49107417

This forecast is in response to the UK having a new PM, And with wholesale changes to the cabinet it is a new government. 
The changes to those in charge of ministries and Johnson's speech carry the message that this government does not want to maintain the status quo, but get on with addressing problems across the board not just Brexit. To an electorate that can see problems everywhere Johnson's idea of tackling everything energetically has appeal.  His problems are that he has a very small majority, lots of enemies in his own party (as well as no support outside his party in parliament) and that he has promised to deliver Brexit by the end of October. The obvious move would be to call a GE hoping that his mood of optimism is contagious and that he can ride this wave to get a big enough majority so that his Conservative enemies can't block him by working with other parties. If he called a GE today its possible that there could be a GE in early September, and if he got a big majority it would boost his chances of hitting his 31st October target. If he does not call a GE today then he would need to recall parliament in order to have the vote to trigger a GE or wait until parliament restarts in September.   A similar timing issue would affect parliament trying to force a GE, The bottom line is if the GE process is not started today the results of a GE would be known until late October. So as a means of helping deliver Brexit by the end of October a GE is not likely to help unless the GE was held in early September. A GE in October would probably not be helpful to Johnson. By then presumably his new ministers will be setting out how they will be sorting out all the UKs problems, but none of the problems will be sorted out. So its just the time when the media will be probing their plans and picking holes in them. For example if Mrs May had called a GE for September 2016 after she had given her speech saying she planned to solve all the UK's problems she might have increased her majority, but she held it in 2017 after saying how she intended to solve social care. The public likes the idea of solving the problem, but does not like any of the means of doing it (just like Brexit).   Advisors such as Dominic Cummings might be willing to shake things up by recalling parliament during the summer, so that Johnson can get a GE vote through. So there is a scenario where a GE takes place in early September, its very high risk, but getting it done before the inevitable reaction to the optimistic mood sours might make it worthwhile. The optimism will sour because like everyone else Johnson says he want change, but has not fleshed what the changes will entail. If everyone agreed what the answers to the problems were, the previous government would have already implemented the changes. So clearly whatever the Johnson government's solutions turn out to be, will be seen by many MPs (and voters) as negatives, Its far more popular to say you will "fix the housing problem" and "fix the social care problem" than to actually do it.  The other GE date scenario is to set the date after 31st October. That is a lot more likely, but would either be because the UK had left the EU with a deal, or had left with No Deal. I don't see how Johnson would get the existing deal thru parliament and I don't see the how a new deal could be negotiated in time. Also I don't see why if Brexit was about to happen why parliament would want a GE that would be too late to change the form of Brexit. So a GE after October is only likely if an A50 extension had been agreed.

Boris's kipper example serves to show all that is wrong with Brexit and with Boris. Boris Johnson makes a claim that purports to illustrate what is wrong with the EU; - that its a over bureaucratic organization that unilaterally imposes pointless rules on hard working citizens and takes away sovereignty from democratic national parliaments. The kippers are packed as they are in order to reduce the risk of the consumer getting food poisoning as smoked fish can be infected by listeria if not well packed. But a story that kippers are sent in protective packing to avoid listeria will not entertain many people. The fact that the packaging rules are set by the UK Government and are nothing to do with EU laws will not excite Brexiteers as they want to hear that the EU stops the UK doing things or makes the UK do things. The fact that the Isle of Man from where the kippers were sent is neither in the EU or UK shows that if you want to export to another country you have to follow the rules of that country. 7. A new referendum? Are you sure? That would just increase the odds of a hard Brexit as time "runs out", and the Europeans move ahead and just fire the Brits.

I am going to be referencing @Anneinak forecast https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/881094 Two things happened yesterday that affect the question; Labour said that any WA negotiated by the Conservatives would not be voted for by Labour unless it included a Public Vote (AKA New Referendum). A vote on the Northern Ireland Bill showed that MPs could (probably) stop a No Deal Brexit. I am going to assume that Johnson becomes the next PM. The TV debate yesterday gave a good idea of his thinking. I see no chance of any version of WA emerging before November that the Conservative ERG would vote for, so the Conservatives alone could not get it thru parliament. Labour would only vote for a WA if the bill included a Public Vote. A Public Vote could not happen before November, Therefore I agree with @Anneinak. the two WA options cannot happen.
(I don't see any chance of enough rebel Labour MPs voting with the PM to get a WA thru parliament if the Conservative ERG vote against. It seems a difficult sell to get Labour MPs to vote for a WA without a Public Vote that their party is willing to vote for if it includes a Public Vote.) Both Johnson and Hunt convinced me in yesterday's debate that the No Deal "preparations" are just bluster. Any one who thinks you could create new border control system in a couple of months is either bluffing (unconvincingly) and/or has never been involved in designing, producing and rolling out any sort of system. Unless we assume the majority of MPs are totally irresponsible it will not happen.   It has been claimed that Johnson might call a GE immediately he becomes PM. I think this is very unlikely. He made it clear in the debate that his whole objective is to be PM (Brexit was his means to become PM) and would not commit to resigning if he failed to leave the EU before November. As both the Conservatives and Labour are only polling at around 20% to 25% support it would be stupid for them to agree to have an election soon, as both parties would likely lose a significant proportion of MPs and the result would almost certainly be a hung parliament  (and they would need to agree to get MPs to vote for an election). If Johnson or parliament waited to see how negotiations with the EU went it would be too late to have an elections before November and then do anything. So in that case an extension to A50 would need to agreed with the EU before setting a GE date.  The case for having a Second Referendum is similar to having a GE. An SR could not happen before November (the minimum period seems to 22 weeks after calling it) so presumably the UK would decide, in principle, have a SR, go to the EU ask to extend A50 and when the EU agreed it would set a date.  (I guess the PM could go to the EU and say "we intend to have a SR" on a particular date, but "setting" the date I assume means setting the date in law.)   So we are left with Revoking or Extending. (I have already rejected No Deal). Revoking is the emergency option that parliament might have to apply if a PM refused to ask the EU to Extend A50. Surely Revoking A50 would be the end of Brexit and of Johnson as PM. Extending A50 would be a very bad outcome for Johnson, but he could dress it up as someone else's fault,  So I am going for 100% Extend A50
