@nigster, @Tetbury, @dowser, @Emil, @Jim2 I don't have the brain wattage that you guys have so I focus on simple things like the words in the question.  This question asks what will happen FIRST. All of the leave options--with the May WA, a new WA or no WA--all can't/won't happen until Nov 1st.  What can happen before that?  revoking A50, extending A50,  and setting dates for a GE or referendum.  Right? Since revoking A50 requires action only on the UK side, it would, theoretically, be quicker to achieve than extending A50 which requires EU agreement, as well. Now, what are the processes for setting a date for a GE and a referendum?  Which process can be faster?  It sounds to me like setting a date for a GE could be much faster than setting a date for a referendum, since the process of defining what the referendum will be on is so much more complicated than the process for calling a GE, either at the behest of the PM/government, or through a vote of no-confidence. So, POLITICS ASIDE, I see the sequence (first to last) as
set a date for a GE
revoke A50
extend A50
set a date for a referendum
all leave options Now, I add in the politics. 

Setting a date for a referendum seems highly unlikely because there's no agreement in sight about what the referendum would be on.  So, that option drops to even after all of the leave options, I think. Revoking A50 is also highly unlikely.  May's not going to do it.  Neither BJ or Hunt would do it.  Parliament won't vote for it.  There'd have to be a GE first.  So, that option falls on the list to after the leave options, too. There's several plausible scenarios which would result in date being set for a GE.   What will the new PM do:  will he call a GE?  Will parliament force him to?   Would BJ call a GE?   I think he'd not want to call a GE, but his hand may be forced by parliament to do so.

 Extending A50 is possible, too, but would it be preferable to the PM or parliament?   If the new PM was for it, then it could happen before a GE was announced or before the leave options.  What does BJ say about extending A50?   It seems to me that what the UK does best is kick the can.  Extending A50 would allow everyone to save face and to continue to promise Brits that Brexit will enable them to have their cake and eat it too. That means that it looks to me like when politics are considered the sequence of events could be
extend A50
set a date for a GE  
leave:  with May's WA, a new WA or no WA
set a date for a referendum
revoke A50 But I'm not too sure of that, or much anything else, either. . .

Thanks @dowser, @Tetbury, @nigster for your responses on dating an election. The Schleswig-Holstein Question is a great corollary for Brexit: the answer to both is 42, i.e., beyond the realm of logical analysis; or 666.
Approaching the issue (and the question) as the Devil’s work may help untangle the “catch-22”s in the plot: 
22.1: Only BoJo would want an election. (The polls do not look good for Labour and the odds are low for an Alliance Government.) However if BoJo moves to precipitate an election (confidence motion or fan-dangling a non-confidence motion) he may well not get the mandate from Parliament. Meanwhile, Corbyn would (or should) only want an election as a last resort to derail Brexit as defined currently. If he initiates a non-confidence motion he may well succeed. 
22.2: If there is non-confidence and we move on to an election it is unlikely that a new government will be formed before Halloween (October 31st). “The Right Thing” would be for the acting PM to request an extension to A50 and for EU to accept, with a sigh. But: BoJo may not Do the Right Thing, or some EU country may be having a bad day and say No.
22.3: Anticipating a motion for another, more specific referendum: BoJo may vote against it, preferring an election - but the DUP may break ranks and carry the motion. Thanks to @Emil @cafebedouin @Anneinak and others for clarifying that the referendum date would be set only after deliberation on the question. In all probability the EU will be asked for extension during this time, and again they will likely accept with a sigh. However, they may demand the question and the date first, depending on when the request is made, and they may say No; revoke first (!)
22.4: BoJo’s posturing about re-negotiation is a sham, and may be a delaying tactic to stall the discouraging but necessary agreements for a well-managed hard exit. If no referendum or election is called first, then there may be an extension towards the end of October to finalize the details. Will the details constitute a “new Withdrawal Agreement”? If so, would they require a vote in Parliament (yes) and would the motion be carried (no). Return to 22.1 and 22.3 with BoJo not looking so good.
22.5: The Conventions: (really! This is no time for navel-gazing.) Will Corbyn make it through to October? Either way, return to 22.4 with Labour resolve for a non-confidence motion in October if Conservatives do not agree to another referendum.
22.6: There are other options, none good.
Recalculating:
-	Give the Devil a 1/6 roll of the dice (dropping out without substantive agreements on security or trade); would increase in late September
-	No existing or new agreement likely
-	For the rest: 50% election; 50% referendum, with referendum split 2/1 towards getting EU endorsement before finalizing the date; all subject to Conservative approval ratings this summer, and to my understanding Parliamentary procedure better.

However,  I'm reminded that this question will resolve on the basis of which happens FIRST, so maybe I've got my forecasts for extending A50 and calling a GE in the reverse order.  Would the UK ask for an extension of A50 BEFORE it set a date for a GE or a referendum?  Wouldn't the UK argument for an extension of A50 be that we are having a GE or referendum? So, increasing setting a date for a GE to 42% from 17%, increasing setting a date for a referendum to 17% from 8% and reducing extending A50 from 42% to 8%. Time is more pressing than some of players seem to think. If the Labour Party's preferred option is to try to get a date set for a General Election their window of opportunity is very small. Presumably Labour would demand a vote of confidence in whoever is the next PM. They can't do that before 4th Sep, (I assume a vote of No Confidence in Mrs May would be pointless because she has already said she is resigning)  because the process for forcing a General election requires two No Confidence votes two weeks apart and Parliament will be closed from 25 July to 3 Sept (Mrs May is expected to remain PM until 23 July). In September Parliament will only be in session between 4 Sep and 12 Sep, it them closes for the Party Conferences and reopens on 7 Oct (I think). If the first Confidence vote had already been lost by then the second vote could take place in that week, and then a General Election could be called it is assumed (no one seems to have tested the assumption) that a General Election requires a notice period of at least 6 weeks. So it appears virtually impossible for a General Election to take place before 31st Oct.  In theory a PM who had just lost two No Confidence Votes could ask the EU to extend A50 to allow a General Election to be held after 31 Oct, but clearly a Conservative PM who had just lost Parliaments Confidence but had the option of extending A50 or allowing a No Deal Brexit to happen would be under a lot of pressure to let No Deal happen.  
Obviously if its already too late to have a General Election before 31 Oct, calling for a vote of No Confidence would not be a useful tactic to prevent a No Deal Brexit happening on 31 Oct.  
It would probably be easier for a Parliament that wanted to block a No Deal Brexit to pass legislation demanding the PM ask for an A50  extension than try to force a General Election.

Its difficult to disentangle what the two candidates for PM will actually try to do about Brexit from what they would like to do in their dreams. Both dream that they will  go and ask the EU to remove the Irish backstop from the WA, so that the pure Brexiteers will help the UK Parliament pass the WA legislation. There seems no evidence that the EU has any plan to just scrap the backstop without replacing it with some similar e.g. that NI only stays in the EU Customs Union and EU Single Market until a totally open, but totally secure solution to the border with Ireland is found, while Britain (UK minus NI) is outside the CU and SM. As most Conservative Party members have told pollsters that  they would not be bothered if NI (or Scotland) left the UK, they would be presumably be happy with Britain outside the EU while NI was in a backstop. But the same is not true of the DUP MPs who would not vote for any Brexit deal that changed the status of NI vis a vis Britain. Without the DUP's vote the Conservatives cannot get the WA thru parliament unless some other party backed it.  Even if the WA was agreed by MPs it would be difficult to get all the legislation through before 31st Oct (as there are only 20 sitting days between now and 31 Oct.  It seems very unlikely that EU would drop the Irish backstop, unless Ireland agreed because EU politicians need to show they are  backing the remaining members rather than helping the UK, that is leaving.  I don't think that either Johnson or Hunt are bright enough to see that their only hope of staying as PM is to call a General Election or another Referendum. The Referendum would need to be on Accepting the WA as is or Revoking A50. The chances of them staying as PM are pretty low in any event, but not doing one of these things will almost certainly be fatal to their chances of remaining as PM.  (A smart PM who had not said he would "do or die could have engineered matters so that "the people" could solve Brexit in a vote. If No vote, then it will be Blame the PM.) So given that Johnson (or Hunt) will almost certainly not get what they want, what will they do when that becomes clear? The myth that Brexiteers hold dear is that the EU always folds at the last minute so presumably whoever is PM will hold out until 31 Oct waiting for the EU to fold. As most Conservative MPs say they "believe" (in Brexit, in the myth that the EU will fold, that No Deal is not a bad outcome) they will not want to sound the alarm before the PM's ship has hit the rocks because if they do try and stop the PM and succeed the Brexiteers will claim that if they had waited another few minutes the EU would have folded. This will be a dilemma for those MPs that think a No Deal will be a very bad outcome. 
I could see midnight on 31Oct being reached with nothing being done. At that point there are still options. The EU could stop the clock and give UK the option of going thru with crashing out, or Revoking A50 or extending A50 again. Revoking A50 would destroy the PM, Extending A50 would destroy Johnson if he were PM, Crashing Out would probably destroy the Conservative Party and the PM.

Updating from June 5th:
Still applicable:
- Expecting Summer Recess with a hard exit PM will give time for a binary option to sink in: hard exit or no exit. 
- Corbyn is committed to not doing anything without a second referendum. 
- Cons are adverse to a referendum. 
- Most Cons will agree to a hard exit or towing the line. 
- There will be strong motivation by many for a non-confidence vote before letting a hard exit happen - say 100%
- A non-confidence motion would see a few Cons and DUP vote their conscience, given that it would be a vote on Brexit
What may have changed/has changed in my opinion:
- Mr Johnson is all but anointed as Cons Leader and PM
- 'push will come to shove' in the first two weeks of Parliament after the summer recess, or directly after the break for conventions - only a week or so before mid-October.
- Mr Johnson may think he could win an election: it is possible he would not be adverse to a non-confidence vote.
Recalculating:
Allow an EE% chance that Mr. Johnson would be pleased to bring on an election - relates to polls and his confidence in converting Brexit Party voters
Say the sub-set of (100-EE)% is
- if there is a non-confidence vote, say there is a NN% chance govt would be defeated. The higher that NN is perceived by the Cons leader the more likely he will agree to intervene with a referendum. Call this probability RR%. However, if faced with a non-confidence motion, the Cons leader may be happy to let it happen. Say RR=(NN)x(100-EE)
The Extend A50 bucket forecast relates to the process followed for setting a date for a referendum and extending A50 - and GJ's interpretation of the question (formality of the action vs. confirmed intent): divide RR% equally between Referendum and A50, say. 
Assumptions:
- 100% certainty of a non-confidence motion or agreement to a referendum before October 31
- Exclude the 'chaos' options if the non-confidence vote happens after mid October. 
- There will be no meaningful negotiation with EU to be shot down in Parliament
- No extension of A50 without a plan. 
- In the event of a hard exit there would be a few logistics negotiated with EU, but they would not be substantive enough to be considered by GJ as a 'Withdrawal Agreement'
This forecast uses EE=25% and NN=75%

In case there is any doubt that forecasting this question is difficult I offer today's example; On the BBC Politics Live today, a Conservative MP representing Boris Johnson gets into an argument as to whether Johnson plans to renegotiate the Brexit WA before November. The MP says Johnson has assured him that the WA will not be renegotiated, it will merely have a few words  added to the Backstop section, which the MP considered too small a change to count as renegotiation. While the studio guests argue if this is or is not renegotiation, a tweet is sent by Steve Baker who is also a Johnson for PM supporter  to say that he has been promised, by Johnson, several other changes to the WA in particular that the European Court of Justice will not have any role during the 2 year implementation period. 
It seems likely that Johnson is promising different things to each MP that will vote for him to be PM. 
So now travel forward a few weeks and Johnson is PM and he goes to the EU (and lets assume they agree to discuss the WA) does he say "I don't need to renegotiate the WA I just need a one line change to the Backstop"? My guess is that either the EU just say "No" or they say "if we agree this one line change can you guarantee  you can get it thru Parliament?" If Johnson says "yes" and the EU agree to the change, but then Baker and ERG (Conservatives) refuse to vote for it because they demand more changes, the EU wil tell Johnson to take a hike. If Johnson says "No" the EU will certainly tell Johnson to take a hike. As the EU is as capable as I am of watching BBC TV they already know that Johnson is telling different supporters different things and that what ever he asked for from the EU will be rejected by at least some Conservative MPs (and almost all non-Conservative MPs) so nothing short of full renegotiation of WA with nothing hidden so no last minute surprises arise, will produce a WA that Parliament will vote thru, and that WA would need cross party support not rely on just the Conservative Party MPs and DUP MPs. It would only take a handful of Conservatives to block any version of a WA as too hard or too soft (especially likely with Johnson as PM). There is not time to do a complete renegotiation of the WA before November even if the EU wanted to. To pretend otherwise is setting things up for a certain failure. So as far as I am concerned Johnson might as well be written off now because his statement that agreeing the WA is feasible before November can only happen if he has a way of getting Parliament to vote for Mrs Mays's WA.

This question can have multiple outcomes that can happen, but what matters is which one will happen first. I will list my reasons for the likelihood of each one, but I think there are only two main things that will happen, given we have 133 days as I write this question, but 101 from the 22nd July, the date when the UK *will* have a new Prime Minister (could happen sooner), and the proposed leaving date of 31st October. 1. The UK will leave the EU with the November 2018 Withdrawal Agreement in place - Parliament returns on 1st September from its summer recess. This assumption is that the new PM tries to pass the previous PMs deal which is a/not their own b/already failed three times with a more important deadline, March 29th. I don't think that a new PM could not at least try a renegotiation over the summer, and the new deal would be have to be passed by the commons and the lords before the 31st . Or the new PM tries to pass the Mays deal, which it will not pass through the commons with the current makeup of parliament.
2. The UK will leave the EU with a new or renegotiated version of a Withdrawal Agreement in place. This is what the new PM will probably want to try to do, but time would not be on his (all the candidates left are male) side, and therefore in order to do this would need a mechanism to get more time.
3. The UK will leave the EU without a Withdrawal Agreement in place. This is not what the candidates left want to propose, and the EU would also not want this outcome. Although the Brexit party may want to see this happen, Parliament and the negotiators have a lot of incentives to avoid this and have already demonstrated they can come up with extensions to avoid this.
4. The UK will revoke Article 50. Almost impossible politically (it may well be a smart negotiating tactic, but come on) and the option of another extension is easier.
5. The UK's Article 50 period will be extended beyond 31 October 2019. I think this is one of the two big options. I would say this would be more likely if the Government collapsed, as the EU does not want to have to suffer a no deal. It is also the option that might be announced ahead of a general election if you were concerned about financial stability, or if the EU agreed to further talks under different red lines (allowing free movement of people for instance)
6. I think this is from the British side the most politically likely option. The parliamentary arithmetic can't change without one, the tories could strike a deal with the brexit party as to not lose too many votes. The result would likely be a coalition but I think the likely PM will see this as the only alternative, to 'gain a new mandate' / provide a reason for a further extension of Brexit.
7. This solves nothing for any party involved, and the debates as to what the question will be, funding etc would take this past the time limit. I do not think it is a serious option and I do not think the consequences have been thought though, *especially* by those proposing it on the remain side who assumes that the only reason they lost in 2016 was because voters were 'not informed' about the risks, not accepting that people weight risk differently. My big assumption is that the EU likes to kick the can down the road and the UK not leaving benefits them, and I think this is a fairly safe comparison. But the main factor here is timing, there is very little time for any of the more complicated proposed situations above to happen. If you think I have missed something please let me know, likewise if you disagree. @annieak @emil

With Boris Johnson leading by a large margin after the first round of the leadership contest, it looks like the harder Brexiters have an upper hand in selecting the next PM.  Assuming that a hard Brexiter will be the next PM, there is zero chance to have a new referendum on Brexit, to have a general election and to revoke Article 50. It is hard to believe that May's negotiated Brexit agreement can pass the parliament with a new PM - 5%. It will likely come down to a poker game - the threat of a no-deal Brexit versus a re-negotiated deal.  I have no clue will happen and so I put these two possibilities having equal chance.   I don't see the rationale of having another extension - this thing has been kicking down the road for so long without having any real solution.  But maybe politicians and bureaucrats think differently.

I last looked at this forecast six weeks ago, so what has changed since then?
The elections to the EU Parliament have taken place. Considering that one of the strong reasons for voting in the UK EU Referendum to Leave the EU was because the UK was culturally different to the rest of Europe, its interesting that the EU Parliamentary Elections appear to show that UK voters changes in political views since the last EU election are almost exactly the same as the EU average change in voting. The centre right and centre left lost votes, the Liberal Democrats and Greens gained votes as did the more extreme Nationalist. As far as this question is concerned I don't detect any signs that the EU's views on a Brexit agreement will be substantially different to the views of the old EU Parliament. So I don't anticipate the EU changing its views on the Irish Backstop before November 2019.  As far as the UK is concerned the big change since I last looked at this forecast is that Mrs May has resigned as Leader of the Conservative Party (but is still PM). It is assumed that once the Conservative Party has chosen a new party leader that person will become PM. It is generally being assumed that this is automatic, but it is perhaps less automatic than it appears. The new Conservative Party Leader will need to show that they "have the confidence of the house". This means a majority in Parliament. Currently the Conservative only have 313 voting MPs, a majority needs 322 MPs (650 - 7 non-sitting MPs - the speaker = 642 / 2 = 321 +1 = 322). As the leader of the largest party the Queen would (presumably) invite the new Conservative leader to try and form a government, but without the "confidence of the house" he (all men in the contest) would not (I believe) be PM. Several Conservative MPs have suggested they might quit the party if a new leader says he will aim to leave the EU with No Deal. In all probability they would not quit until nearer November (if at all) but the Conservatives would still need to get the support from at least 9 other MPs to have a majority. It is assumed that the DUP could be persuaded to continue with the current support arrangement they have with Mrs May's government, but I am sure they will have a price.  And if a couple more Conservative quit even the DUPs 10 MPs would not be enough. This could well delay the formation of a new government and the appointment of a new PM. Obviously much of this forecast depends on what the next PM does. The UK local elections and the EU parliamentary elections have shown that both the Conservative Party and Labour Party would risk losing a lot of seats in a UK Parliamentary Election. Its very difficult to predict what the outcome would be but the Conservatives would almost certainly loose most seats, but no party is likely to have an overall majority. So it seems likely that a new PM would prefer any other outcome than a General Election.   While several Conservative candidates for PM have said they would actively aim for a No Deal Brexit, those whom their fellow MPs considers crazy enough to mean it have been knocked out of the running, while those whom their fellow  MPs assume are just trying to sound as if they are crazy enough to mean it, but would not actually go ahead with No Deal have been forced to make clear that this would be the last resort. The majority of MPs (from all parties, but mostly Conservatives) seem to have the delusion that you need to threaten No Deal in order to win negotiations (No Deal is of course a reasonable position if it means maintaining the status quo, but its a crazy position if No Deal puts you in a much worse place than the status quo, when the status quo is on offer. Maybe the education system needs to be looked at if MPs don't understand this point.) So I think leaving without a deal will not happen. Conservative MPs would resign, Attempts to prevent MPs voting to stop a No Deal would probably destroy both the Conservative Party and the UK's constitution.    So can a new PM do a Brexit Deal with the EU before November? I suppose a new PM might have slightly more chance than Mrs May did, but the problems remain the same. MPs have got it into their minds that they will not vote for the deal agreed in November 2018 mainly because they don't like the Irish Backstop. So is it likely that the EU will agree to change or remove the Irish Backstop before November? This seems very unlikely especially as the EU's current Commissioners have agreed their position with EU Governments and the outgoing EU Parliament and have stuck to their line for many months (the principals were agreed in 2017). The current time table would suggest that between now and November there are only about 60 business days at most. It seems very unlikely that the EU would fold days before the new Commissioners took over. So I don't see this happening. The only way I can see to get a deal agreed before November would be for a new PM to convince MPs that he had changed Mrs May's deal in some way, but for the deal to in fact be exactly the same as the WA that has been agreed by the EU and rejected by Parliament three times. A great leader might be able to pull it off, but I don't see anyone of that caliber running for PM So the most likely thing to happen is as the end of October comes and no Brexit progress has been made the question of extending A50 again comes up. The EU will want to know why the UK wants to extend A50. To hold a General Election will not happen. I suppose the UK could claim that they could do a deal with the new EU Commission that will start in November. A new PM would surely not want to agree to another referendum, but it might be the only option they have to find a way out of Brexit. But this would only be a way out if the option on the referendum was the November 2018 WA or Remain in the EU. (any other answer would just repeat the same loop again.) But that would surely be a better way out than No Deal or Parliament Revoking A50 without the cover of another referendum.  But another referendum would require an extension of  six months. 
My feeling is that the EU would prefer a extension of 6 months for another referendum rather than No Deal or forcing the UK to Revoke A50 as the only option to avoid No Deal.

Given the success of the Brexit Party during the European Elections at the end of May, Revoking Article 50 seems a out of the question.  However Britain remains wholly divided on all other aspects of Brexit and there is no momentum in any direction.  Parliament will likely have to ratify any decision before 31 October and “no deal” does not command a parliamentary majority.  There is no reason to believe that the EU will be open to a major renegotiation of the Withdrawal Agreement, but minor tweaks are possible.  This would might be viewed as a renegotiated version for the purpose of this question.  The Brexit preparation process is more or less on hold, as a successor as PM is being identified.  Therefore the most likely scenario is that Britain will remain unable to act at the end of October and ask for a further extension.  In any event, this question would have to be asked before the deadline expedites.  And hence it would be asked before any of the exit events take place.  A referendum or general election would require an extension of the deadlines allow for the preparation which is asked for first ... the decision to ask for a GE or R would likely precede a notice to the EU that an extension is necessary.  A GE doesn’t seem wise for either of the parties commanding the strongest position in Parliament.  There has not been a parliamentary majority in favour of any form of second referendum.

To answer this question I proceed by elimination, trying to figure which are the least likely options.  It is highly likely that the conservatives will elect a pro-brexit candidate, that promises to get the UK out of the EU regardless of consequences. (95% chances).  I don't see how such candidate or even a more pro-remain conservative for that matter can revoke art. 50 without calling a referendum first or general election (short of  a natural disaster or a war this option is highly unlikely). ..... proba 1%   The only only thing all conservative can agree on is that a general election would have disastrous consequences. General elections are  unlikely would be result of a split of the conservative, 7 conservatives would need vote no-confidence in their own government. Given the precedent of  "Change Britain" this means that 7 MPs would essentially choose to give up their seats. This is not impossible, but I expect that potential conservative rebels (such as D. Grieve or Hammond)  will explore every possible alternative before voting no confidence in a conservative government, and I expect that the next PM will also try to avoid to put them in such situation. ......Probability =5%         I don't see the EU offering a new deal or even being open to negotiating one. They would jeopardize their credibility, open the door to very difficult subsequent negotiations with the UK and in addition France's Macron would likely veto it.  Proba 10%  UK leaves without a withdrawal agreement. On the plus side: this is the default option and the new conservative PM position will likely be "no deal is better than a bad deal" (not unlike the previous PM). However, there are two issues: 1/ it is easier to say "no deal is better than a bad deal" from the back benches than in downing street, where one will face the consequences of no deal. 2/ The arithmetic of Westminster has not changed. With current speaker John Bercow (remainer) indicating that he intends to remain in his seat this option will be difficult. Proba: 20%  The least unacceptable options are to extend one more time or call a referendum. This would occur after taking "negotiations" with the EU to the brink no-deal exit and possibly Parliament finding a legal way to force the government  to avoid "no-deal" brexit.   Between the two solution a referendum is more likely, as extending one more time would put the next PM once more in an humiliating position vis a vis the EU (worse than Theresa May) and bolster the Brexit party ratings at the expenses of the conservatives. In addition the  EU could possibly refuse. Therefore I put extension at 25% and referendum at   37%

This is a tricky question in all regards (especially the breadth of it). In order to maintain a bit of a heading I'll assume a 5% baseline for every option and work from there. Now to break down each...  - Leave w/ Nov. 2018 deal: I see this as highly unlikely though not completely infeasible, will leave at 5%
 - Leave w/ new deal or no deal: This will be highly dependent on whoever becomes the next PM. Playing the odds there gives about a 50/50 on the two
 - Revocation of Article 50: Again dependent on who wins the PM, but unlikely in comparison to the deal/no-deal options (as much as I want this to be the outcome)
 - Article 50 extension: Highly unlikely at this point, will leave at 5%
 - General Election: Also highly unlikely at this point (political suicide for the cons. party)
 - New referendum: This isn't horribly unlikely, but would be HIGHLY dependent on the new PM (Would effectively have to be either Jeremy Hunt or Rory Stewart)
Shifting a bit toward them leaving without a deal and away from extension or leaving with the current deal since the conservative front runners seem to be pushing that line.

The spectacular arrival of Nigel Farage's Brexit Party and the failure of Theresa May's compromise deal has shifted the centre of gravity within the Parliamentary Conservative party towards leaving on 31 October. The likelihood of 'revoke', 'GE' and 'extend' will depend largely on the strategy of the winner of the Tory leadership election. Candidates have so far given us different amounts of information regarding their strategy, varying from nothing (eg. Sajid Javid) to being quite specific (eg. Esther McVey, Dominic Raab). Hopefully things will become somewhat clearer as the leadership election progresses and the candidates are more forthcoming about their plans. However the margins in parliament will remain extremely tight whoever the leader is. There are about 650 MPs and yet the motion for a second referendum was defeated by just 12 votes, the motion for a customs union with the EU was defeated by just 3 votes, and the government's working majority is just 6 MPs. The odds of a referendum seem to be higher now. Corbyn and much of Labour back a referendum [1].  The new Conservatives leader will want to try to renegotiate the Withdrawal Agreement. They will be able to use a no-deal as leverage against the EU (assuming the new leader is a hard liner, this may serve as an effective threat, more on that below). It is hard to see how they could get the votes without support from a strong Labour contingent.  The EU elections results indicate that the country is more split on Brexit than one might have thought before, which will likely drive MPs apart as well. This will make it more difficult to pass a new WA. A referendum or a GE offers a way to resolve the differences in Parliament. Tories will want to avoid a GE as the last UK election and the EU election didn’t work out well for them. They will want to avoid a scenario where Labour pushes for a GE and thus be more willing to go along with a referendum. To watch/resolve:
* Who will be the new Tory leader? This is particularly important for the odds of a no-deal exit.
* Will Tories be able to get a new WA in time and elicit enough votes for it without most of Labour (who seem in support of a referendum)?
* What would the EU prefer to avoid? A no-deal exit or concessions needed for a new WA (e.g. the Irish backstop). Currently I am guessing that the EU will prefer a no-deal (knowing that the UK will be hurt hard by this too) than to throw Ireland under the bus (and show dis-unity). This lowers the chances of a new WA. I am leaving a sizable likelihood for an extension on the off chance that one is agreed before a date for a referendum or GE is officially set. Adjusted to account for May's imminent departure and the candidates announced so far for the Tory leadership. The Tories will not want a general election and also do not want to have a further referendum.  The DUP will not want to have a GE as this is likely to diminish their power.  As Tory + DUP is a majority, it is extremely unlikely that there will be a GE before the end of the fixed term period.  May's deal died once May resigned.  Not all candidates for Tory leadership want a no deal Brexit and the current parliament are not likely to vote for one, so chances of this happening are still fairly low but could happen by default if no other action is taken in the meantime.  Most likely scenario is that the UK will return to negotiations and will ask for an Extension if no agreement has been reached by October 31st.

I am lowering extension chances on the following argument: it now seems to me (contrary to arguments by e.g. @nigster) that an extension does not have to happen before a date for a referendum or GE is set. For, even if an extension is not granted in time for the GE or referendum, the UK can always revoke A50 and the EU knows that. Overall, my assumption is that the extension is not a binding constraint but a procedural one, and as such it will fall in line when a political agreement is reached. As with other topics of international law, politics sometimes (often?) comes before norms and procedures.

My thought process, with sequence of buckets revised:
set a date for a referendum on Brexit?
 - requires Parliament to define the proposed terms of exit - which cannot happen until PMs collaborate on changing process, e.g., to enable ranked choice - which is highly unlikely, say 0
leave with the November 2018 Withdrawal Agreement in place?
 - tried a few times; failed consistently; as above, would require collaboration and process change  => 0
leave with a new or renegotiated version of a Withdrawal Agreement in place?
 - ditto above => 0
set a date for a General Election?
 - the "right thing to do" because all MPs, not just PM May, wear this failure. But would the Opposition risk failure at the polls by calling a vote of non-confidence before mid October? (80%, say – note: dates for this summer recess are not published yet; in the last two years, the House has returned from summer recess in the first full week in September. ) And would both the Conservatives and DUP both resist it? (33%, say) => 0.8 X 0.67 = 0.53
https://www.parliament.uk/about/faqs/house-of-commons-faqs/business-faq-page/recess-dates/
leave the EU without a Withdrawal Agreement in place?
 -  this is the dangerous one. Sound government would repeal the European Union (Withdrawal) Act 2018 https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/European_Union_(Withdrawal)_Act_2018 until the terms of departure are agreed to by Parliament (which will never happen). However Boris Johnson and others, possibly, would leave the fuse in 'as a negotiating tactic' and just might let the bomb go off, if made PM, and if there is no election first => 0.8 x (1-0.53) X 0.5 = 0.19, say
https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2019-05-24/tory-favorite-boris-johnson-says-he-wants-a-pragmatic-brexit?utm_campaign=socialflow-organic&utm_source=twitter&utm_content=brexit&utm_medium=social&cmpid%3D=socialflow-facebook-brexit
revoke Article 50?
 - if the Withdrawal Act was repealed until terms are agreed to by Parliament it is conceivable that Parliament revoke Article 50 until terms are defined and passed by referendum, say – all of which is highly unlikely, say 0
- similarly, if the clock runs down and EU hardens its line on allowing extensions it is conceivable that Parliament repeal the Withdrawal Act and revoke Article 50 until terms are defined – all of which is highly unlikely, say 0
- if Parliament decides to do a U-turn on Brexit it is not likely to happen without a referendum => 0
Article 50 period will be extended beyond 31 October 2019?
 - another form of 'Groundhog Day'; possible => 1.0 – 0.53 – 0.19 = 0.28

(I feel No Deal is more 30% and extension more than 50%, and am trying to work out everything.) It's a messy situation so I started from the bottom up: I see no real prospect of the original WA passing. This should probably be 3% or something but I've simplified. I am likewise very very unconvinced a different deal can be agreed given the indicative votes were so split. If a new PM proposed a Single Market Brexit or similar it could probably pass the Commons and EU Parliament, but I see very little prospect of a Tory PM doing so (or Corbyn, for that matter). I really don't think there will be a snap election as the Tories voting for it are a necessary component of holding one and they think they'd be destroyed. Even if they might be willing to risk it, Tory MPs fear Corbyn becoming PM far more than a normal Labour leader. I think that makes them even more risk averse for holding an election. I don't think the UK will revoke unless the EU won't extend, and I think they will. Having said which, there is some chance of that. If a deal is struck which can pass the Commons I think the way it would get to 326 MPs in favour (or however many are needed factoring in tellers, Sinn Fein, etc) would be if it had a 'confirmatory vote' built in. So I think a date being set is possible. HOWEVER this would be a referendum after we left the EU I strongly suspect - so I think this being the first thing to happen is very unlikely. If May quits over the summer, which is highly likely, then her replacement is likely to be a more hardcore Brexit supporter - many frontrunners are explicit No Dealers. Though Parliament has forced the PM to extend once, there's a significant risk that a No Deal PM would cause a No Deal, either 'intentionally' or simply by causing the EU to conclude there is no point in negotiating with them. Having said which, the fundamental remains that the Commons has a large anti No Deal majority and the EU is so far very reluctant to do so. This is therefore my favoured outcome.

The situation is complex and difficult to assess. These are my views:
1. Leave with existing WA implies that May gets her the deal through parliament on her fourth try (at a moment where she seems weak and after European elections that will likely end disastrously for her party). I think the option is therefore unlikely. A new PM is also unlikely to try what May has failed at several times, but I guess it is still possible for May to reach a cross-party agreement that falls within the frame of the current WA. 2. Leave with a new WA before 1 November implies a renegotiation (be it in part) of the agreement with EU and have it pass parliament in 5.5 months. With the elections, summer recess and a likely change of the PM, all falling in that period, it seems improbable. I think it is possible with a new PM and maybe some shifting of red lines or if the government and Labour reach an agreement. 3. Leaving without a deal. I do not see why the government (or a majority in parliament) would do that, but sometimes ... 4. Revoking, Article 50. The government's position is to deliver Brexit. I can only imagine the government revoking Article 50 before November 1, in some crisis. 5. I think more time is needed and extending beyond 31 October is the most likely option at the moment. If no cross-party agreement can be reached with labour, a solution will take time. The current paths to Brexit create problems and risks that the EU expects the UK to resolve. At the moment, there is little incentive for the EU to change the status quo (they have already offered a longer extension before and will most probably do it again). Within the UK, blocks are very divided, and the government is unable to unite and solve the issues. There is no easy solution out of this situation.  6. I am not sure how the decision to hold a General Election would come about. As the government is somewhat unpopular, there is not much incentive to call for general elections. Should more significant numbers of conservative members start moving to other parties, a general election might happen.

7. As the situation drags on and the situation does not resolve itself, another referendum might be called before November 1. Politically it might make sense (it is a "democratic" solution), But: 1. The government will have to decide on the referendum question (To be fair, the referendum would need one remain option and more leave options, watering down the leave vote). 2. The last referendum caused a situation that was very difficult for the government to deal with (they are weary). 3. Many people will not understand, they have voted for something, and now they have to vote for the same thing again (Some will argue it undermines the people's trust in the government). 4. What if the referendum does not lead to a solution but only further divides the people, some will argue.

May's government and the Labour Party could reach a Brexit agreement. For over a month, May's Conservative-led government and Labour, the main opposition party, have been discussing a Brexit agreement that both sides could support in Parliament. The negotiations include several topics, such as post-Brexit workers' rights and the incorporation of some EU single market rules and standards, but the main obstacle to a pact is Labour's demand that the United Kingdom remain in a customs arrangement with the European Union. May's government has consistently objected to staying in the EU customs union, noting that it would prevent the United Kingdom from negotiating goods-related free trade agreements with other countries (though trade deals covering services would still be possible). Recently, May has made ambiguous statements about staying in the customs union, but her Cabinet is divided on the issue. Some ministers worry that such an agreement would lose too much Conservative support in Parliament and not gain enough Labour support.

Seven buckets. • 1) Leave with the current Withdrawal Agreement.
• 2) Leave with a changed or new Withdrawal Agreement.
• 3) Leave without a Withdrawal Agreement.
There is no parliamentary majority for any of the leave options because the House of Commons is 3 to 1 remainers. • 4) Revoke A50.
Parliament will not directly overrule the referendum result without some sort of democratic cover story eg. an election or another referendum. • 5) Extend A50.
The default option if none of the others happen is A50 being extended again. • 6) General election.
A GE could happen if the Tory/DUP alliance loses it's majority in parliament which could happen if either the DUP withdraw their support or some Tory MPs defect, for example to the Brexit Party. (Note: TIG/CUK defectors have said they will support the government in a confidence motion.) • 7) Brexit referendum.
Parliament will not approve a repeat "are you sure?" referendum because it is undemocratic. A referendum on the terms of May's deal would take forever to arrange.

I am approaching this question by starting with what most MPs don't want to happen.
There are probably less than 10% of MPs who would countenance Leaving the EU with No Deal. If circumstances arose that made No Deal the default I believe MPs would block it by forcing the Government to Revoke A50.  
MPs would only Revoke A50 if the choice was that or No Deal. There would be a huge complaint from 35% or so of the pubic if A50 was revoked without some very good reason. In spite of the Government being unable to govern and the official opposition saying they want a general election both main parties will avoid risking it after the bad results for both Conservatives and Labour in last week's local elections. Projections of the result of a General Election suggest no party would get a majority, and neither Conservatives or Labour would find it easy to find  coalition partners (the LibDems will not be offering any help as being in coalition with the Conservatives nearly wiped out the LibDems in the last election).  The remaining options are more difficult. 
There is not much chance of a referendum on Brexit unless it is a referendum on a specific form of Brexit. For there to be a  specific form of Brexit agreed to by the EU and the UK Parliament any referendum would not be based on a unicorn wish list (as was the 2016 referendum) and so be pointless because no one would know if what they were voting for was a deal that even existed. Even if the idea of having a referendum was agreed by parliament a date could not be set until legislation had been passed. If the referendum question included the option of accepting a Brexit proposal or Remaining in the EU, it would make no sense to hold the referendum (let alone set the date for the referendum) after the UK had already left the UK. So if a referendum does take place it has to be before leaving the EU.  It would take at least 22 weeks to arrange a referendum. To hold a referendum before 1st November would need parliament to agree to it almost immediately because several weeks after a referendum had taken place would (assuming the result was to Leave the EU) still require legislation to take place, so its almost certain that if a referendum was to be held the EU would need to first agree another extension to A50. Therefore before the date for a referendum could be set an extension to A50 would need to be agreed (but the question here is not will an extension be agreed, but will it actually take place first.)
Labour has adopted the rather odd position that any deal that they don't back should include another referendum, but any deal they do back does not. Clearly if the government could get a deal through parliament that Labour did not back it would be able to ignore Labour's idea of a referendum on it. So on Labour's current plan they would never back a referendum on a deal they liked and would be unable to get a referendum on a deal that the government could pass without Labour's support. So I don't expect the Labour leadership to be able to stick to this line.
  There is probably little chance of extending A50 unless it is to hold a referendum and a date would need to be arranged for that before 1st Nov. Therefore there is little chance of reaching 1st Nov without one of other of the other options being reached first.  The WA agreed in Nov 18 could get agreed by parliament, but does not look probable. Its been rejected three times so for it to be agreed would require either the hard line ERG faction of Conservative to back it alone with some MPs from opposition parties to back it or a lot of opposition MPs to back it.  It is possible that some more ERG Conservatives will cave in and back the Nov 18 deal, but it seems very unlikely they will all cave in. What difference will the local elections last week and the EU elections in three weeks make? What we do know is that voters are unhappy with both the Conservative and Labour parties. What is less clear is why they unhappy. Presumably some are unhappy because they want the UK to Leave with no deal, some are unhappy because they want to Leave the EU with a deal, and some are unhappy because they don't want to Leave the EU at all. It is thought that about 75% of Conservative voters wanted to Leave the EU, so presumably 25% of Conservative voters are unhappy because the Conservative are no listening to them and that they are unlikely to  continue voting Conservative. Of the 75% of Conservatives who it is thought support Brexit the opinion polls suggest that most of them would prefer a No Deal Brexit to the Nov 18 deal, so there would seem to be little electoral benefit to the Conservatives in forcing the Nov 18 deal though parliament when 75% or 80% of there voters don't like it. 
Of the opposition parties in parliament the DUP supports Brexit, but is very firm in its opposition to the Nov 18 deal so they are very unlikely to change their minds and back it. The LibDems, the SNP/PC and Greens are all firmly for Remain, so are very unlikely to change their minds and back the Nov 18 deal.
That leaves the Labour Party. It is estimated 75% of Labour voters are not in favour of Brexit. The leader of the party is less clear. Most constituencies that are held by Labour voted Leave in the referendum, but of course many or most who voted for Leave might not have also voted Labour (presumably in constituencies won by Labour MPs there are lots of voters who voted Leave in the referendum but vote for the the Conservatives or UKIP in most elections). Most Labour MPs supported Remain. So for Labour MPs to change to support the Nov 18 deal they would have to vote against their own judgement and vote against the views of the majority of Labour voters in the hope that they don't lose more votes than they lose. And take the not inconsiderable risk that those constituents who did indeed vote to Leave probably hate the Nov 18 Conservative Brexit deal. I it were me I would not go down route because its is almost certain to lose votes.     Finally there is the possibility of a re-negociated withdrawl deal. Its possible in theory but presumably would only happen if Mrs May resigned and there was a new PM. The EU would not want to re-open negotiations, and although 1st Nov seems a long way ahead between now and then we have the EU Parliamentary Elections (May) no sitting EU Parliament (June),, the summer holidays (August), agreeing the new EU Commission (September/October?). There does seem much time for the EU spend on negotiations.  (I assume changing the Political Statement that goes with the Withdrawal Agreement does not count as re-negotiations.) So the bottom line is that Brexit is a mess with no way forward if everyone sticks to what they are currently saying. The least damaging way out would be for the Conservastives after a change of PM has taken place to agree another referendum. Then the public can be blamed for whatever the outcome is.
